551.content: Shockingly good. A game where you'd think it'd be a half-assed spinoff for some easy bucks *feels* like the mainline entry while retooling the gameplay itself into a action-but-still-tactical setting. If you liked P5R and can at least tolerate action combat I don't see how you couldn't love hanging with the Phantom Thieves again.

554.content: Definitely give it a try if you enjoyed Persona 5/ Royal. Otherwise it's likely not worth your time

555.content:
As someone with 400+ hours in the original Persona 5 game, I can say without a doubt that this is a worthy spin-off. The game not being turn-based did scare me a bit and yes, it is very difficult in the first 5 or so hours but after a while I got used to it and when you learn to mix combos and weaknesses it gets really fun to play (the teammates are also super fun to use; Yusuke, Haru and Wolf especially), Jails (basically dimestore Palaces) are very creative and beautiful to look at, the boss fights are incredible and I honestly liked the boss fights in Strikers more than than original P5. The fanservice was done very well, and the music is fantastic as usual (Axe to Grind and What You Wish For blows Last Surprise and Take Over out of the water). The new characters - Sophia and Zenkichi are both phenomenal additions with sick Persona designs and I found both of them to be complex and riveting (and also in the case of Sophia, the most adorable character of All Time). Also runs very well except for 2 crashes. 

I do have some gripes but they're mostly minor. The biggest complaint is that it's not entirely stable - I've crashed twice in the game for no reason. Bond points are tedious and if you want to max everything you have to get to bond level 99 which is asinine. The lock-on system is truly horrendous as well.

While it may be questionable whether it's worth 60 dollars, it is overall a fantastic spin-off which proves that while Atlus might milk the franchise, they're at least putting effort into it. I recommend this game especially if you loved P4G and P5/P5R. 

And of course, I, like everyone else, look forward to the inevitable Persona 3 and Persona 5 Royal PC port.

559.content:
This is more than the average Persona spin-off. It is a true sequel to Persona 5 (not royal, basegame P5) as it keeps the superb character writing of the original while not falling to the general "Persona spinoff character archetypes".
The gameplay might be drastically different to the usual turn-based combat that the series is known for, but they've managed to make a great sequel that has such a different feeling.
I will say though, the final few chapters of the story fall back on basically repeating story arcs from P5 but with minor twists. The game is aware of this somewhat, and it does come up as a joke that this is incredibly similar to what the thieves has already experienced.

If you like Persona 5 in any way, I would strongly recommend this game, just remember to save often as the game tends to crash on me randomly

560.content:
It's good. It's damn good.

This is not a dynasty warriors - style offshoot, a la the fire emblem or zelda warriors games; this is a true, blue sequel.

Story wise, it kinda rehashes the themes of the third semester in P5R, but that's not a bad thing. Some things are better touched on, and some things are less approached. It's a different look at the ideas. In addition, there's a lot of something both P5 and P5R were lacking: team building. The crew hangs out a lot. I mean, A LOT. there's good elaboration of character dynamics, a lot of humor, and it leaves you feeling warm inside the way well written characters do.

The new characters are well written and enjoyable (much more so than Kasumi, in my opinion). They find their place fairly quickly and latch on to you the way the others did in their own time.

Gameplay wise, it's dynasty warriors with some twists. A lot of components of traditional persona combat are integrated, but moved to a reaction based real time style- think of it as the changes from Dragon Age: Origins to DA2, but better. (in my opinion, much better). Strengths, weaknesses, technicals, baton passes and showtimes- they're here.

The soundtrack is, as expected of the persona franchise, fulla bangers. Look foreword to it.

I was glad to hang out with these weird kids in japan again, and I was not disappointed.

561.content: A great blend of the Warriors series hack and slash mass combat and the Shin Megami Tensei / Persona combat mechanics.

564.content: it's a fun Dynasty wars crossover that's not like the others out there. However I will say I do miss the social links and going on dates and what not with that. Strikers is a lot more combat oriented than hanging out with the homies oriented. Still though it's a fun game and if you want to see the crew back in action this is where to go. Although this takes place after P5 and has no association with P5 royal.

567.content:
A fun muso game with a familiar cast and world with the same staples Persona 5 is known for such as it's great sound track and its style is also faithful. Combat is enjoyable and the way combos expand the more you play as each character is a good way to get you playing everyone and seeing each thief's arsenal while in combat. I really liked seeing the existing cast interact more in what felt like a more natural way. With new cast members thrown into the mix, it only strengthens the character line up within Persona 5's world. Certain characters however do end up boiling down to their singular trope such as Futaba being more egregious or Makoto doubling down on her motherly role within the group. 

Overall story was interesting enough to keep me wanted to see how it would progress. However, there were a few moments that felt repetitive in the game play when it came down to locations. Some areas feel copy/paste of one another which is a bit of a let down considering what potential could have been met.

The main negative however that I'd consider the real reason behind whether this game is worth getting on Steam is that it crashes. Not just once or twice but multiple times. Personally, it crashed 15+ times but some friends have had it crash much more or much less. It is not a great port over onto PC and with these issues being so irregular, be prepared to what you could end up dealing with.

568.content: You definitely have to play persona 5 first before playing this (not royal). Besides that, its such an amazing blend of the warriors genre with persona 5 gameplay. One of my favorite games of the year at the moment.

579.content:
This game is great. I really enjoyed it.

It's getting a negative review from me after 20+ hours because the people who are being fucked over by the constant problems the game has deserve a voice.

This game has a ton of issues when it runs for many users; I had the issues up until I forced the game to run in Administrator mode, and that literally fixed all of my problems. I haven't had a crash since day 1; on Day 1, I had three crashes. I found the suggestion from a user who had tried making sure the game ran in Administrator and it fixed all of their issues.

I have friends suggesting that the Kyoto boss area is basically unwinnable right now, and it has a crash right after that you can't get past. I'm looking to try and see if that happens to me, as I'm a few in-game days away from that particular date.

This game is great, the port itself needs some tweaks, but apparently Atlus nor Koei Tecmo plan to do shit about it.

I've lost a lot of respect for Atlus, and now I'm not sure if they deserve any more of my money past this point; Persona 4 Golden was a beautiful port, and it was patched with the majority of its issues solved within days.

It's been almost two weeks from this game's release and not a fucking word of anything getting changed or improving. Dev's want to sweep this under the rug and get away with it.

If you can, and you also reviewed this game, swap it to negative and get this game noticed by the Dev's so they do something.

584.content:
I genuinely really like this game. It's significantly better than other Warriors styled games I've played in the past (though BOTW: Age of Calamity was just as good as this game, I'd say) and it manages to retain Persona 5's style really well despite being so different gameplay-wise. Once you get the hang of it, the battle mechanics of this game feel really fluid and satisfying to pull off, and while these types of games are known for being spammy, I think with the amount of variety between each playable character and the varied settings you encounter, the game does a really good job with not becoming stale. I think that the character interactions are fun and that the plot progression was more well developed than I was expecting out of a Warriors-type spin off. It really felt like I was playing Persona 5 and the only thing that was different was how I hit things.
The reason I'm currently not recommending this game (a reason I'm gladly willing to change my recommendation for if fixed in the future) is because it crashes and softlocks itself far often. I've made an obsessive habit of saving after literally every small action I take because every time this game has to load something in, there's an unnecessarily high possibility of it crashing. At the time of this review, I have about 35 hours in this game (end of the 5th jail) and I was having a really good time with it, until I reached a point after a boss fight where loading in from the metaverse softlocks the game. I know it hasn't crashed because the game still responds if the controller is disconnected, but I'm otherwise met with a black screen I cannot hope to progress from. From the research I did into this issue, it seems my computer isn't the only one softlocking at that exact point in the game.
I implore Atlus/ Koei-Tecmo to patch the game so that the PC port is actually functional, because I think it's a real shame they let this great game be released while this broken.

585.content:
My first mushou and a great complementary experiencie of Persona 5 royal. It has many crashes, but if u run the game as an administrator they disapear.

Hope u guys enjoy this game as much as me

586.content: A great return to the series continuing off the events of the first game you get to explore the world of persona 5 in a whole new way! I kinda miss the turn based combat but other than that the game is extremely enjoyable and tops it off with another great story shaped by the commendable voice actors.

587.content:
Picks up right where Persona 5 left off, which as a returning player from the original Persona 5 feels great. The game will probably make less sense for people who aren't familiar with the original Persona 5, but the gameplay is still solid regardless. 

There are a lot of QoL changes made in Strikers that just weren't there in the original Persona 5, some to accommodate the new Dynasty-Warriors type combat, while others are just generally nice changes (such as no punishment for returning to the real world from the Metaverse). 

Overall if you've played the original Persona 5 and don't mind the switchup in the core combat loop, I highly recommend this game. If you haven't played the original Persona 5, you can still enjoy this game for what it's worth but you may miss out on references made to the original game.

588.content: It's not a true JRPG unless you get to fight a God. (again)

590.content: More Persona and SMT content on Steam, please.

593.content: Great addition for the Phantom Thieves. Great story, awesome music, and fun game play. Highly recommend.

594.content:
This game is amazing!
A must if you played the original Persona 5 or Royal. While I initially had my doubts and worried this would be just a Musou-kind cash grab, it feels a lot more like Persona 5-2 would be like. The quirky characters, the second to none soundtrack and having a peek at more cities in Japan are all super enjoyable. If you've been to Japan, you'll immediately recognize Kyoto, Osaka, Okinawa and many more locations!

The battle system can be a bit tricky in the beginning (and very lengthy towards later bosses), but it rewards skills and planning, which is an additional metric to perceive progress in the game.

During my playthrough, the game only crashed once. I lost 15 minutes of progress, so make sure you'll save at every opportunity you have just in case.

I only feel sorry that this is a game that can be only fully appreciated by gamers who played Persona 5, it's sad that there is no port available just yet. 

Definitely recommended!

595.content:
This game is great (I have not beat it, im up to the final "act") If you enjoy dynasty warriors combat and love the world of persona 5 then this is the game you didnt know you needed. For those who have not played baseline Persona 5 I would heavily recommend you do so before playing this game. P5S feels great to be back into the world of Persona alone let alone the refreshing combat that gives it a new feel and twist. The characters are the same lovable idiots we grew with through P5 and seeing them again is awesome, added with a few new people and its a fantastic dynamic. If you have played any other persona game you know the music is great and the way they personas work in this new combat feels natural. 

PS: Hard mode is really hard at the start and well worth the challenge if your like me and hate yourself

Edit: 45 hours and I finished the game, 9.5/10 I bought it for 75$ and id happily spend that again

596.content:
[h1] ▬▬ 🆃🅰🅺🅴 🆈🅾🆄🆁 🅷🅴🅰🆁🆃 ▬▬ [/h1]

[hr][/hr]

The Phantom Thieves are back in this new action-packed sequel to the [b]original[/b] Persona 5 game. [spoiler] Meaning Kasumi does not exist in this game, Atlus please add her as a DLC later maybe. :) [/spoiler] With a new threat posing the world, the thieves are reunited together to kick some more ass.

[b]Persona 5: Strikers[/b] introduces a new hack-and-slash combat system to give the series a fresh take. As Atlus always delivers, there is also incredible UI transitions, music compositions, and stories to explore in the world. By buying the Deluxe Edition, you will be granted access to the digital interactive artbook, soundtrack, and some behind-the-scenes making of Striker's music- on top of that, you will also receive some bonuses in-game to aid you in your battles.

[spoiler] SPOILER ALERTS: Do NOT peek at the artbook until you're finished with the game, the artbook contains spoilers. The opening cinematic to the game also contains a tiny portion of spoilers, in case you're wondering about that. [/spoiler]

This game will have you traveling across several cities and towns based in Japan. You will meet new faces, discover hidden treasures, find an abundance of different shops to buy a variety of items from, and clear "Jails" (which are pretty much a twisted variation of the old "Palaces", you will find out more about them in the game).

All-in-all, if you are looking to expand your knowledge of the Persona universe, or you just want to beat up a bunch of shadows and bosses, this game is likely for you. 

[hr][/hr]

Below are my own opinions about the game after clearing through the game and having 100+ hours of experience. Currently on my way to 100%-ing the game's achievements. Whether you agree or disagree to my opinion(s) is all entirely up to you. I have a bias towards the Persona series, but I will try my best to be truthfully honest about this game.

[h2] NEGATIVES ABOUT THE GAME [/h2]
While this game is overall really good, I can't say this game goes without having a few issues that comes with it straight out of the box. I'll get the negatives out of the way first.

[list]
[*] My biggest complaint are the random, constant game crashes as well as the infinite loading screens. No matter what you try to do, it seems you can't do anything to fix them. Playing full-screen or windowed-borderless mode causes them more frequently, so I usually play on windowed-mode. You can also try lowering the graphics, but I doubt that'd help. My only tip is to SAVE OFTEN- YOU WILL CRASH. Until they send out a patch to fix these crashes, save often because there is no autosave. I've lost a few hours of progress due to this, the same goes to my friend who's had more crashing issues than me.

[*] Keyboard controls and assisted-aiming feels really clunky. I've played on both keyboard and gamepad, the controls still feel somewhat clunky but once you adjust it should feel fine. The target assistance in the game feels really off, Sometimes I want to ambush a certain enemy, but it ambushes an entirely different enemy. Or even when I want to lock onto a rail to ride on it, I end up doing something completely different.

[*] The anti-aliasing option seems... odd? Not sure how to describe it, but I just left it as it is. Some people might have a problem with it depending on your graphics card.

[*] The DLCs aren't really worth buying separately. You can easily grind the content you get from the DLC. Either buy the Deluxe edition and don't look back, or buy the regular game and play it as it is. Trust me, you'll be fine either way.
[/list]

[h2] POSITIVES ABOUT THE GAME [/h2]
Finally, the positives about the game. There really is a large amount of positives I want to point out from the game, but I'll try to tl;dr it.

[list]
[*] The storyline is how you expect it to be from a Persona game. You'll be going along for a roller-coaster ride of plot twists, fun and sad moments. You'll easily get attached to some new characters as well. While the gameplay experience isn't as long or sophisticated as the original Persona 5 game, you will still get a nice feeling of satisfaction after clearing the story.

[*] As I mentioned earlier, Atlus feeds us yet another game full of art-beloved UI transitions and new musical compositions. If you love Persona for what it is, you'll love this game. Expect to be jamming to Persona music for a while.

[*] While the battle system has changed into a hack-and-slash style from the original turn-based system, I can say for certain that this is a completely new breath of fresh air. Even by saying it's just a hack-and-slash is not fair to this game, there's much more to it that you'll explore. I actually prefer this over the original combat system. It's just full of constant action and doesn't feel boring at all.

[*] END GAME CONTENT- MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD: While there is no clear end-game story, additional content comes in the form of New Game+; essentially you can start a new game with all of your stats carrying over to the new game. You can also opt in to try out Merciless mode, the hardest difficulty of Strikers there is. Once you start Merciless mode, you can't back out. There is also some content you can only unlock in New Game+, so you'll have to play through the game at least twice to unlock all the achievements if you're looking to do that. It feels really nice beating bosses at maximum difficulty.

[*] Each Jail is unique- unlike Palaces from previous games. Every jail you visit will feel fresh, as they're designed to be a new experience from other jails. Each one will have its own atmosphere and aesthetic. Play the game for yourself to find out how different Jails are from Palaces.

[*] You are able to switch between the Phantom Thieves and play as Makoto, Haru, Ann- hell even Morgana. Each thief has their own playstyle. Mix and match your party and find out which strategy works for you! (note: you can't play as Futaba, she's a support character for obvious reasons yet again)

[*] Flashy all-out attacks and showtimes are still present. You will feel like a bad-ass performing these while Last Surprise plays in the background.

[*] PERSONA ON PC!?!?!?!?!? One step closer to Persona becoming the norm for PC gaming.
[/list]

[hr][/hr]

[h2] GAME RATINGS [/h2]

Controls: 6 / 10 - 7 / 10 if you're on controller
Gameplay: 8.5 / 10
Storyline: 10 / 10
Music: 11 / 10
Waifus: too powerful to rate

bought the game 3 times for pc + switch, as well for a friend. worth.

[h2] CONCLUSION [/h2]
[hr][/hr]

[i]tl;dr[/i] [b] game good, but please add royal to steam, I have too much free time.[/b]

That concludes my review of Persona 5: Strikers. Good luck out there, fellow thieves-

600.content:
Great game, ver fluid combat and great for those who played Dynasty Warriors and other games of the sort. However, I cannot recommend it to new players due to the fact it is a continuation of Persona 5's story. Overall, I recommend this nice game, but perhaps it should add a bit more content in the future.

601.content: While it felt like a sequel to Persona 5 I still had my issues with it. I felt the writing of the monarchs were way too similar to the palace rulers from Persona 5. Nevertheless, the game was fun to play and the hack and slash combat was quite interesting to say the least.

602.content:
After eight hours of play I experienced my first crash. This reset *roughly* twenty minutes of dialogue / cutscenes but I figured this was a good time to detail my first impressions.

Everything from here on can contain a spoiler, read the TL;DR if you want.

If you have experience with FF: XIII or Kingdom Hearts, you'll feel right at home. The majority of the combat is face-paced, hack'n'slash gameplay that feels enjoyably intense. While not up to Devil May Cry levels of complexity, the fights are very fun. Team member selection is vital to not getting teamwiped, even at the early levels, typical for an Atlus game.

I think this game was designed for a controller in mind, if you have one: play with it. Otherwise, I highly recommend rebinding almost every default combat / interaction key in the game. While initially frustrating, like most games on PC, a good keybinding setup is the first skill in any game. 

If you're new to the genre or Atlus games, don't be afraid to play on easy. I don't claim to be an expert to these type of games but, as a very competitive individual, I did get sent back to the loading screen more than once before completing the first dungeon on normal. Don't expect to be a god at this game if you have limited to no experience w/ the combat of other Atlus games. As is usual of this brand: the skill ceiling is high, the floor is rock bottom. And, trust me, the game is trying to make you experience rock bottom.

As for sound, top notch. The music has caused me, more than once, to sit back in my chair and take my hands of the controls. Some tracks are nostalgic from P5; others completely new. Each it's own an experience worth noting. The voice acting is solid. It really helps engross you in the story that would, otherwise, be boring to read.

Graphics are what I expected: anime. The cutscenes are well done w/ a mix of 2D and 3D animation. I want to make a note: I am not a fan of 3D modeling / animation BUT it's done well. The combat feels fun and looks great.

TL;DR

Sound: 10/10 - The soundtrack is amazing, voice acting engrossing
Graphics: 9/10 - I don't have a problem w/ 60fps and graphics that come straight from PS4. Feels Persona 5, man.
Gameplay: 9/10 - High learning curve. Can be very punishing but rewards good strategy. Initial keybindings are T R A S H.

I experienced my first game crash an hour before writing this review. This game has bugs.
Regardless, I would definitely recommend this game to anyone that enjoys strategic, fast-paced hack'n'slash games.

Edit: 34 hours and still playing. Suffered another crash that reset me the final 1/3 of a dungeon. Another 30 minute setback; nothing major. Frustrating, but both of my game crashes occurred after extended sessions (6+ hours). Rereading my initial impressions: all of them still have merit. My gut tells me I'm entering the final stages of the story. I'll give my final thoughts when I finish.

617.content:
This game is a must buy for people who have played the original or the Royal version of Persona 5 (or at least in cases have watched a playthrough). The story is as funny and emotional as ever and there are improvements on almost every level; The music is great, the characters still keep their development from the last game, the UI somehow tops the original, and the combat is very fun and addicting. I would suggest this game for everybody but the characters often refrence moments and characters from the original game and don't explain complex things over again like the metaverse or Morgana.

This section is to grade how worth it the digital deluxe edition is:
The digital deluxe edition is hard to say the quality off. In order to access the content you need to push the Play button specifically in Steam for the game and it will ask whether you want to play the game or the 'app'. The quality of the app is very sketchy as right from the start it has a Unity watermark at the beginning. It gives you a Digital Art Book, A Behind the Scenes Video, and a Soundtrack Player:

Digital Art Book:
The digital art book was disappointing to me. It is nice to see the artwork and some concept art here and there it doesn't have any writing from the artists about what they were trying to do or the challenges they had to face in making it. This is the worst part of the package.

Behind the Scenes Video:
The behind the scenes video is pretty much a non narrated documentary that shows how Lyn and Lotus Juice made the opening song "You Are Stronger". It mostly focuses on the difficulties of having a non native speaker sing english and it really shows how they are masters of their craft, so much so to where Lyn was able to find out that the reason her singing sound off was because the mic was just 2 inches too low, which is very impressive to me. I'd say if you like Behind the Scenes and Filmmakers commentaries you'll like this, however it should be really easy to find it on youtube.

Soundtrack Player:
The soundtrack player is ok. It just feels like a standard music player with a Persona Skin layered over it. The main thing that sucks about it is that you can only listen to the tracks in this player and have to have it open in order to listen to them, no downloads. You're better off just finding the soundtrack on youtube.

The main reason for wanting to spend $10 extra dollars though would be to have the music play in game. You get some in game items that you won't care about but when you get this edition you get the battle themes of every main line persona game!... except for Persona 5 and Royal... from what I heard you have to have save data from those games in order to get those tracks... which means only Playstation players can get them. However, it is really cool hearing music like, Mass Destruction or Reach Out to the Truth play when you start combat, it even has music from Persona 1 as well which I do not know the name of but really like. If you like these tracks than its only 10 bucks and you get to pick which tracks you dont want to here and in each battle they will randomize which track you get.

644.content:
Didn't finish the story yet, but so far I am really enjoying the game.

I love the art style, the music and let's not forget the level design. The fact that there aren't to many games today that do this is a shame.

As far as gameplay goes, I really enjoy both turn based and warrior type games, so the switch in style is no problem for me (sad to see the game get some hate on account of this). From my point of view, the way they incorporated Persona 5 mechanics into this game is well done. Even tho there is button mashing involved, I often find myself looking at it from a strategical point of view (which character should I use, what enemy should go down first, what buffs/debuffs to use, should I use SP move or combo etc)

Regarding the story, at this point in time I can't say much, but so far it meets my expectations. I do miss some aspects that have no been included, mostly secondary character stories (as Persona 5 does have some nice characters), but I wouldn't say it's a deal breaker.

I did experience some crashes, however in my 30h of gameplay, this only happened twice, none of which have been in crucial moments like boss fights, or even jail exploring, so I can't say I've been bothered that much (would still be nice to get these patched tho).

While exploring you will see objects popping in and out of existence, but usually it's small stuff, like rocks and to be honest, most of the time I hardly notice them (since I'm usually looking out for enemies, chests, junk and so on).

Despite the flaws mentioned above, I still think it's a great game and would recommend it to any fan of the series and hope that sometime in the future, we will be able to enjoy Persona 5 Royal as well. ^^

648.content:
I don't believe in unbiased reviews, but I do believe in going into a game unbiased before playing. I can't say I did that with Persona 5 Strikers because I was so dang excited to play this game.

Upon finishing, I'm happy. Some people say this is a good template for future games, but they're wrong. This is a definitive and refined version of a Persona 5 sequel, but it lacks the emotional depth and sense of time that makes the mainline games so compelling and amazing.

But what Strikes does well is get the gang who you've already enjoyed a 70-110 hour game with, and take you on another adventure with them. This is a game for those of you who maxed the Confidants in Persona 5, spent a year in Tokyo stealing hearts, and decided you want just a little bit more.

I enjoyed the road trip aspect, as it feels like a more grown up theme than a growing up theme - one of my rites of passage into adulthood was travelling with friends, and Strikers captures that perfectly. This is a game that has grown up with people who played Persona 5 a few years back.

With that in mind, the writing is solid. Sometimes the characters feel like archetypes, but that's par for the course of a Persona sequel. I see it as more akin to the characters being more comfortable in their own skins, openly being parodies of themselves in a lighthearted fashion. It's also not as on the nose as, say, Persona Q was in this regard, so that's a good thing. I went along with it, at least.

My biggest reservation was that Omega Force were developing it. I hate Musou games, and I won't lie, when this was first announced I felt a pit in my stomach - I asked myself if this would this be a Persona game I skipped. Thankfully, it's more RPG than Musou to its benefit. I still prefer the turn-based combat, and I miss the Confidants/S.Links, but the action RPG combat complements the more streamlined Persona experience in general, giving the game a sense of pace that isn't needed in a mainline release. I'm amazed that they pulled it off, but they did.

About the only flaws, for me at least, with Strikers are the bugs. When it works, the game runs like a dream, but there are some visual glitches in All Out Attacks that are jarring, and the amount of times the game crashed or froze was, frankly, unacceptable. I'm hoping Atlus/Omega Force go in and fix these issues, but I can't help but feel it's tainted my experience. My best advice to deal with them is save often and hope the game doesn't crash during a long story segment.

Bugs aside, this is a solid game. It's not a groundbreaking title, but it is a solidly made game that sets out to do a thing and does it. If you've played Persona 5 and wanted one more adventure with the Phantom Thieves, this is £55 well spent.

653.content:
[h1]Before I start, lemme first suggest you to not buy the deluxe edition.[/h1]
Bonuses, including the soundtrack, are locked behind an app. Which means you can't listen to it on another device, or in your favorite media player.

[h2]Now, the game itself...[/h2]
Well, the game itself is pretty good.

It is important to [b]note that this is a sequel to Persona 5 (Not Royal)[/b], you can play it and kind of understand it without having played P5, but you'll enjoy it much more with knowledge of the events preceding the game. This game further develops the characters from P5 and brings new ones to the table, which are all pretty well written.
So far, the story is pretty decent, nothing stellar, though it's hard for me to judge, not having finished the game yet.

Gameplay is a solid mix between Persona 5 elements (Elemental weaknesses, baton pass, all out attacks, and of course personas) and what you'd find in the warriors series of games (basically inane amount of enemies and unique character combos). Some people seem to think this game is a musou. I'd argue that while it borrows a lot from the genre, it is, in fact, mostly just an Action RPG, which is not a bad thing in the end. However, due to the nature of the game, this can easily feel repetitive after a while.
Difficulty is a bit confusing though. Normal encounters often ends in seconds while bosses can be extremely frustrating at times.

Graphically the game is decent, UIs are stylish as you'd expect from a Persona game, but... the anti-aliasing they use (FXAA) is terrible, and affects the UI, this is pretty bad. I really recommend to disable the game's AA and make use of [url=https://reshade.me/]reshade[/url]'s SMAA instead or, if your PC can handle it, [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2405510545]supersampling[/url] to make things look good.

The soundtrack is full of bangers, as you'd also expect from a Persona game. Some of the tracks here are the best Persona 5 and its spin-offs can offer. Play this with good headphones.

Now... Not all is good. Be warned that the game is locked at 60/30 FPS and sometimes randomly crashes when loading cutscenes. Save often.

If you can handle its little flaws and quirks, then this game is a pretty solid entry in the Persona franchise. And a pretty good game overall.

[h2]If you don't have the time, here's the tl;dr...[/h2]
* Game is a sequel to Persona 5 and will be much more enjoyable if you played it before.
* Game is not a musou. It's an Action RPG where encouters are made of massive amount of enemies. The battle system itself is a mix of mechanics you'd find in Persona and Musou games.

+ Story is pretty good and the new characters are great.
+ Battles are pretty fun.
+ The soundtrack might contain some of the best tracks in the series.

- The difficulty curve is pretty weird. Normal encounters are easy, bosses are frustrating.
- Graphically "decent". The Anti-Aliasing is terrible.
- Framerate lock. (60/30 FPS)
- Game sometimes crashes.

[h3]Obligatory "Please bring Persona 5 Royal to PC pls".[/h3]

656.content:
A very solid game, if you're a fan of Persona 5. The game has a good narrative, that adds fun and good new characters to the universe. I would say that the story is a bit cliche but its follows the standard Persona narrative. If you have played a Persona game you most likely will know where the story is heading.

I had some issues tho, the game continues Persona 5's annoying group dialogue, the group hardly gets to talk about their life's or enjoy the time and instead most of the dialogue is spent talking about the Phantom Thieves instead of something more interesting or funny. This was an issue in the last game and continues to be an issue with this game. Atlus also for some reason chooses to end the group events really quickly. I was very annoyed when this happened since it happened alot during 5, THIS GAME IS ALL ABOUT HANGING OUT WITH THE GROUP AND THEY END IT SO FAST. sorry, but these choices is what makes 5's group a lot more worse than 4's and 3's since the group feels more like the Phantom Thieves instead of a friend group that you can relate to. But if you were fine with it in 5 you will feel the same way about it in this game. 

There is also a lack of optional story content. Most of the optional content is done through requests, that let you go back to previous places to do different challenges to unlock things. All the characters have their own mini side request for you, and all it does is give more dialogue. I felt that this was a huge misfire, i understand not adding a huge side portion of the game, but at least give us a scene or two with these characters by ourselves, to further explore them. They have ONE scene where you get an option to pick one of the characters to go on a trip with you, that's it. Side content is one of the best parts of Persona games and with so little here it makes me a little disappointed.

Combat is very fun. It is also very engaging with many different characters that open different ways to play. The only issue is that certain parts of the game are not very challenging on hard.  Again, with Persona games most of the boss battles are hit or miss, they rely on similar gimmicks to defeat them. Once you learn this gimmicks most boss battles will be finished in the first try. Combat is really fun, like i said, but it seems that because they added so many things to help your character, they really made the game less difficult in the process. 

Again, Atlus does an amazing job with the visuals. The ui in this game is better than the last game, adding flashy things to the ui makes going into a menu much more cooler. The many different places you will visit on your roadtrip are very cool looking. They do a good job capturing the different looks of Japan, from the country side too how different the cities look in the different provinces. The music is also amazing, most tracks return from 5 but the battle music, the backround music, and the remixes of 5's tracks really add alot to the game.


I had a few issues with the port. Most of my issues were with crashes during loading, for some reason i had none when in combat. Very annoying since it does not allow you to save whenever you want. 


Even with my issues with the narrative and other parts of the game, P5 Strikers is still a great experience that i think every Persona fan should play.

658.content:
Strikers serves as a good sequel to Persona 5. It's not perfect by any means, but it's good. It continues the story of the Phantom Thieves and takes you on a fun adventure with the thieves again. The road trip concept is really fun and you get a lot of interaction between them, though the writing doesn't feel as solid as vanilla P5 or Royal did.

As someone who's had minimum experience with the warrior series, playing Strikers was easy to get into. However, I would recommend turning off the automatic camera as soon as you can, as it made me confused playing. Also pay close attention to enemy weaknesses and abuse that as much as possible while getting combos and All Out Attacks.

Early game, try and grind out money as much as you can, upgrading the bond that raises money gain and bond exp asap. It gets easier as the game goes on but I find myself running out of money quite often if you wanna gear up your entire team at once.

Being able to pause the game to use Persona skills or items is very nice and allows you to think about your next move.

The game does feel lackluster in some areas though, most notably in dungeon length and some story elements. Some dungeons are longer than others, while a few are only floor long. They don't spend a whole lot of time on some characters or moments either and some characters feel one dimensional. But if you're just looking for a good time and wanna smash some buttons and are a fan of the Phantom Thieves, I would recommend it.

661.content: Finally Joker from Super Smash Bros. Ultimate has his own game

662.content:
I was a bit worried at first that this game wouldn't live up to Persona 5, and well, I shouldn't have been. This game is fun. It's a lot of fun. The combat is so much fun, it's fun to go looking for it instead of avoiding the JRPG vanilla Persona 5 which gets tiring after 100 battles of grinding. It also doesn't take itself too seriously, I mean, you can ride a skateboard and run over shadows with it. You get to do realtime combat with all-out attacks, follow-ups, one-mores, technicals, persona skills/swapping, baton-passes, etc etc. It's a blast to play. I HIGHLY implore you play the game on Hard for your first run. This game NAILS hard mode so well. Unlike other games that make their higher difficulties bullshit and unfair, this game makes it fair. Not only are the enemies tougher, but so are you. You do more damage as well. Combined with dodging and countering, it makes for a super fun combat experience.

The story is pretty damn good so far too. It feels like a proper sequel to Persona 5, though any part of the game like the base game does feel a bit more empty / simplified. Keep in mind that this game is a sequel to the vanilla Persona 5, NOT ROYAL. All the characters are the same as ever and enjoyable to watch and interact with. While Confidants/Social-Links are not present, you still get to bond with your friends a good amount not only in combat but in the real-world through events; reminiscent of Persona 4.

The biggest complaint you'll probably hear from this game are the bugs. The game has this weird tendency to crash whenever you leave/enter the Metaverse. I'm unsure why. You can luckily save a lot in this game, especially right before you load a new area so it shouldn't be that much of a hindrance as long as you save. The game also has a 60fps cap and some poor Anti-Aliasing which I hope will be fixed with a patch. It's not enough to make the experience any less enjoyable, I just hope it's fixed soon because it may be more buggy depending on the hardware.

Overall, very fun game. Definitely worth the price. It's around 50 hours I've seen from other playthroughs. Not too far off from the length of Persona 4. There's a good amount of fan-service here. I highly would not recommend this game if you haven't played Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal yet, as you probably won't have as much of an emotional connection with the characters / plot as you would with. The DLCs aren't very worth it in my opinion, unless you get them from the Deluxe version. The All-Out Attack Pack seems to be relatively worthless, while the Legacy BGM Pack is a bit pricey and only worth it if you're a big Persona fan. (Or just like Mass Destruction)

670.content:
First of all. [h1] Hoooooo boy [/h1] Props to Omega-Force/Koei Tecmo, and P-Studio for making this game happened, and to Atlus for publishing this game to steam (praise be to Atlus). I will gladly buy any MegaTen related games.

Okay so, I'll make this as concise as possible.
The story (although a direct continuation from the base game) is basically a reimagine of Persona 5's with a bunch of changes specifically for this spin-off. I'm just gonna say it follows the same structure, that's it (for those who have played, you'll know what I mean). It actually reminds me of the movie called HER because of how the plot heavily uses artificial intelligence as its main topic. Expect a lot of dialogue since this is still a persona game.

The gameplay is good no doubt about that, actually great. Who knew that a game that uses the combination between musou combat with persona mechanics would actually work wonders, I never thought it would be this good. Each character you control has different combat style and special ability. It's really the highlight of this spin-off.

Probably the complains I have are the price and possibly, the end game content (I have my doubts on this one though) since when you finish the game, the only replayability value that this game will give you after finishing it are new game+ (you can totally 100% achievement in the 2nd playthrough) and a new difficulty. I really hope Atlus will update this game with new content, although it's unlikely to happen because this game was released in Japan a year ago and (to my knowledge) there had been no update since then.

All in all it's a good game, as expected of Atlus. Even though they really milk this series hard, you can bet the spin offs of each game are done and polished really friggin well. A definite must have for those who enjoy both persona and musou combat type of games.

675.content:
*IMPORTANT* 
This game crashes ALOT, at the worst time possible. I'm not sure why; to make things worse, the checkpoints to save the game are quite far in between so uhh, the anxiety of hoping the game won't crash while you're far away from a save point is stressful. So if you're playing, remember to save as many times as possible. Redoing what you did from the past 3 hours is not fun. 

Anyways, Persona 5 Strikers is a nice sequel for fans of Persona 5 (Royal). However, the combat is a musou-type game, being completely different from Persona 5's turn based combat. Although, it is very interesting to see how they incorporated hack and slash with the tactical use of personas & baton passes.

The overworld exploration is satisfying, being able to walk around Shibuya, Sapporo, Osaka, and so on with your pals is a nice feeling. 

One thing to note is how the new Velvet Room functions. With the removal of social links, you can't get bonus exp for your personas from social links. Instead you can level up your personas through the use of PPs (Persona Points) which is a little disappointing but it's fine.

To further explain on the removal of social links, Persona 5 Strikers introduces a mechanic called Bonds to replace it. With bonds, you may unlock certain bonus perks like "Extra Money Dropped Per Battle" & so on. You can get bond points from playing through the game.

It's a game to play if you're interested to see what's up with the Phantom Friends after the first game. Not so for the depth of the combat/gameplay, Persona 5 (Royal) still triumphs on that part. 

Some mechanics from the first game were revamped or changed to be better/worse. It's up to you to make your own opinion on it.

686.content:
Spoiler Free!

-Story: This is basically Persona 5-2. The story is a direct continuation of P5, and so if you haven't played the first one, you'll definitely be lost in this game. The writing quality is on par with if not better than the original. 
-Characters: There are some points where the original Phantom Thieves feel exaggerated, but for the most part they're very strong. Not nearly as flanderized as previous Persona spin offs. The new cast members are excellent additions. It's impressive that even with 10-ish characters, no one feels left out of the story. Also Haru got her screen time.
-Gameplay: The combat is simple enough to get into, but has enough elements to make fights feel like more than just button mashing. Weaknesses, One Mores, Environment attacks, etc. all help keep you thinking about how to attack.

Aside from a few nitpicks here and there, I would say this game is excellent. Very fun combat and a great sequel story. The main limiting factor is if you haven't played P5. If you haven't played it, I wouldn't recommend this game. The combat is fun, but it's not enough to sell the game if you're not also interested in the story. Play P5 first so you'll understand these characters and what they're talking about when they mention past events.

708.content:
Strikers is a very welcome surprise. While it may look like a simple Dynasty Warriors clone with a Persona skin, the reality is that this game has a LOT of depth behind it.

The action-based combat retains a lot of the systems at play in P5 and P5R - elemental weaknesses, technical attacks, status moves, buffing and debuffing, 1-More attacks, All Out Attacks, Baton Passes - you name it and Strikers has most likely implemented it in some fashion. In addition to the core systems, each character feels fantastic to play - each boasting unique movesets, abilities and progression paths, as well as displaying a lot of their personality in their fighting style. To put it simply, there's a lot more to the combat than meets the eye, and those who have previously played the original Persona 5 or Royal will appreciate the small details here.

The story so far (around 16 hours in) feels very lively thanks to the strong returning cast of characters as well as the two great new additions, Sophia and Zenkichi. The English version brings more fantastic performances which give the game a unique charm, and while the stakes don't feel too high at the moment, the relationships these characters have with each other make each moment feel endearing.

The music, my god the music. Straight up bangers everywhere. Do yourself a favour and listen to one of the new battle themes, Daredevil. If that doesn't get you excited to beat up some demons, I don't know what will.

A caveat I will mention and the one gripe I have with the game do far is that ultimately it is a sequel, meaning it's difficult to recommend to new players who didn't experience the original game. You could probably enjoy Strikers by reading a synopsis of P5's plot and characters, but really you would just be doing yourself a disservice. As great as I've found Strikers as a massive fan of its predecessor, the lack of a PC port of the original makes it a very hard sell.

If you're willing to look past that, or you've already a fan who has played P5 / P5R, you will most likely fall in love with the Phantom Thieves all over again in Strikers.

Great heart to heart moments fill the space between intense combat and great story telling. This game will take your heart!

Slight performance issues with the PC port. The framerate is capped at 60, and game logic is tied to the framerate. There's two modes: 30fps mode and 60fps mode. On 60fps mode with my GTX1060, I can't even maintain 10fps on medium at times, whereas on 30fps mode, I'm comfortably locked at 30fps even on high graphics. It's very bizzare. 758.content:
Well, time to give a review on the sequel to one of my favorite games of all time.

[b]SPOILER FREE[/b]

[b]Story[/b]

Persona 5 Striker’s story is probably the most disappointing part of the game. Keep in mind that I did not care for the og Persona 5’s story so I had some doubts about this story going in. I thought the story would be bad due to the same reasons I disliked P5’s story, but the things that irked me in this game are different than what irked me in P5. The story is good. It plays with some ideas and themes that work very well. It has emotional moments that work well and the story sets out to do what it wants to do. That is be a summer road trip story around Japan with the Phantom Thieves facing a new threat. My problem is that the story plays it SUPER safe. [b]Spoiler:[/b] [spoiler]It’s almost a repeat of og P5’s story, which is a shame.[/spoiler] It’s also very predictable. If you think to yourself “this person(s) probably the bad guy,” you’re most likely right. It’s very easy to tell where the story is going. Again, it’s not bad. I still very much enjoyed this story over og P5’s. It just has so much missed potential that completely bums me out. 

Whatever the case, you NEED to play og P5 before this as the game 100% assumes you know that game through and through already. Hopefully, they release og P5 or P5R so pc players can play that before this.

[b]Gameplay[/b]

Now, THIS I can get behind. Like many, I had some fears going into this game as I felt this game would be yet another mindless Musou game where you spam attacks and win. And while spamming attacks can get you far pretty early on, it won’t carry you much farther. P5 was half a JRPG and half a social sim. This game is 100% an action RPG. Some will be disappointed by the lack of social sim stuff, but I think the non inclusion of it allows for better pacing in the gameplay, and including it wouldn’t make much sense for the type of story and gameplay Strikers is going for. The new BOND system is a simple yet effective alternative to it I believe. The fighting itself lends itself so well to the warriors’ style of combat. Persona elements like weaknesses, technicals, personas, etc mix so well with it. Each character is a joy to control and each one is just different from one other. Each one of them has their own gameplay purpose. The combat is engaging, and constantly asks you to stay on your toes and use the most of your arsenal since not doing so will result in you dying FAST. Try spamming the attack button on bosses or bigger enemies and see how fast you can die. Using weaknesses and technicals as well as knowing what combos to use is key in beating anything in this game.

The Jails (which are similar to palaces to P5) were all fun to explore and it was joy to see just how creative they could get. Seriously, most of them were fun going through, obtaining loot, doing requests (which are fun and rewarding except the ones where you have to go to an area without getting caught fuck those), and beating shadows was a blast. Some of the beginning Jails are a bit too close in structure for my liking, but the game quickly switches it up, so it’s not a big deal. I do, however, feel that the game got a bit too easy at the end due to just how overpowered spamming weakness and technicals can be at times. I was playing on hard and while it was certainly ballbustingly hard early on due to SP drain, the game got a bit too easy at the end for my liking.  

Other complaints include the lack of gun upgrades. I get the omission of social sim stuff among some other things, but no gun upgrades or customization? Why? That makes no sense since I actually like using guns in this game. Such a weird omission. Furthermore, persona fusing is super basic for seemingly no reason. I don’t understand why they simplified Persona’s robust persona fusing to such a simple state. However, other than the complaints I mentioned, I found the combat overall to be exceptional and constantly engaging. 

[b]Characters[/b]

The writing in Strikers is incredible. This game got many laughs out of me and made me feel a lot. However, the writing for the more emotional moments can get a bit too on the nose for my liking, a common problem for Persona, unfortunately. The villain(s) were all fantastic in how they went about their way of doing things instead of the one-dimensional cartoonishly evil villains in P5. They’re all fantastic. However, some backstory for some of the villain(s) gets thrown in your face like 20 seconds before fighting them which felt cheap, even if it was effective. The main characters (Ryuji, Ann, Haru, Futaba, etc) all remain the great characters they are, but they see little growth in the main story. I mean it’s there, but not enough in my opinion.

Now to keep it as spoiler-free as possible, I love the inclusion of Zenkichi and Sophia. Sophia is an adorable muffin that sees an unbelievable amount of growth in the story. It’s to the point where I consider Sophia to be one of my favorites in all of the Persona series. Zenkichi was amazing as well with a lovable personality and real growth, although not to the extent of Sophia. But they both remain absolutely incredible inclusions to the series.

[b]Music[/b]

It’s Persona. What do you think? Of course, it’s incredible. The remixes of P5 music as well as the original music in Strikers are all fantastic. [i]Counter Strike[/i] and [i]Daredevil[/i] being personal favs.

However, the audio mixing could use some work. The characters become REALLY difficult to hear during boss fights especially with the music is blaring. This can be remedied by messing with the audio levels in the in-game settings, but I hate that this is even an issue.

[b]PC PORT[/b]

What a disappointment. Firstly, the positives. The game runs at a stable 60fps all the time. I only ever saw frame drops during cutscenes and the velvet room of all places. Other than that, the performance is solid.

Now for the negatives. This game LOVES to crash. It mainly ever crashed for me during fast travel or loading screens. During my 60 hour journey, I crashed a total of 7 times. [b]7!!![/b] Sometimes I would lose upwards of an hour of progress. Do you know how much it sucks to bust your balls on a difficult boss only for the game to crash afterward without saving? Next, the game options are poor. The game is capped at 60fps. I don’t know if this is an engine issue or if the devs were too lazy to uncap it or what. Furthermore, the game still looks poor. Not the style, mind you (P5 style is still present here in all its glory), but the game doesn’t look enhanced at all for PC. Textures can be muddy and the UI quality REAKS. WHY IS IT SO PIXILATED?! Overall, a pretty disappointing port. Also, RIP mods.

EDIT 03/17/2021: New update has been pushed today that [i]seems[/i] to have fixed or at least remedied the constant crashing. So that's cool.

[b]Closing thoughts[/b]

Overall, my expectations were blown away by this game. I was expecting a mindless button masher that would give me some kicks based purely on seeing my favorite characters get back together. It is so much more than that. It’s got its issues, sure. It’s not perfect and some things really drag the game down. However, it does so much right at the same time. This isn’t just a spinoff, it’s the true Persona 5 sequel.

766.content:
The closest thing we'll get from Persona 5 on PC until Atlus ports the thing itself or (preferably) the Royal remake.

Overall, the game is great. It is basically Persona 5-2, but with a complete change in gameplay. If you enjoyed the original game, this title is a must. I'd say this is an almost perfect adaptation from the turn-based style to a hack-and-slash type of game, keeping the same Shadows weaknesses, strengths and spells.

However, it has its flaws. By the time I'm writing this review the game kept crashing randomly, either while loading a new in-game rendered cutscene (which can make you lose quite a bit of progress in the first dungeons) or when entering a Jail. The Anti-Aliasing messes with the text a bit (not something that makes the game unplayable, but it feels a bit weird). 

The Keyboard and Mouse Button Configuration is also severely lacking. It's not as bad as only having preset controls like Mega Man Zero/ZX Legacy Collection, but anything to the right of "Enter" is unbindable, which means anyone who uses the Arrow Keys will have a really hard time playing unless they have a controller.

But still, the game is awesome and well worth of being a sequel to Persona 5.

789.content:
As someone who never really played Musou games, P5S was originally an odd concept but i was willing to give it a shot on account of it being more Persona 5 and a good excuse to spend time with the Phantom Thieves. 

I expected it to be a Musou game with a P5 skin but what we have here is a Persona game with Musou mechanics. The charm and style of Persona is dominant and is present in everything. If you enjoyed the cast and story of P5, but not the combat, i would 100% recommend this as it truly feels like a P5 sequel with action combat and no social management (but don't worry, you'll spend plenty of time in running around, in cut scenes and story beats with your crew. 

Overall, as a huge fan of P5, this is a must. The combat is fast pace and refreshing and absolutely captures the essence of the original game. I wish it did have some social stuff but as a spin off, it's fine as is. 

My one slight negative is that if you never played P5 or watched the story, they don't really explain much and it does jump right in after the events of P5 so new players, be aware that some of the game kinda expect you to know what previously happened. 

On the technical side, i'm playing on an ultra-wide monitor at 3440x1440 with a 2080ti and the performance is flawless. constant 75+ fps. No frame loss but i will say that at this time, the game does not support ultra-wide so i get black bars on the side do restrict it to 2560x1440. Not aware of any workaround for that yet.

790.content: I just beat this game and did all the side quests, if you love persona 5 at all, you should too. It has a couple flaws such as many decisions not having much consequence, some early game resource management problems, and the ending being slightly underwhelming, but overall still amazing. I absolutely love Persona 5 Strikers

818.content:
Just rolled credits, and man this was pretty great.

I've never enjoyed a Dynasty Warriors type game, and also felt weird that they were making a canonical sequel to the original. But honestly, this game really really impressed me. It felt like Persona 5 in pretty much every aspect. It didn't feel like a budget title, they really went all out. From what I understand, this is probably the best game Omega Force has put out.

+ Fun gameplay
+ More time with the main cast
+ The whole english dub crew being back is great.
+ The main plot was pretty good. A bit more predictable than P5/R, but still really nice and better than I expected.
+ The two new characters are great, [Spoiler]Gramps[/spoiler] in particular. 
+ Surprisingly fleshed out city locations that give some of those P5 vibes
+ Ran really well on my 8700k/2060. 1440p @ 60fps, super sampled quite a bit. After that, it loses that jagged look of the consoles and looks just like the original.

Nit-picks (These are all really minor):
- Persona 5 Royal is non-canon in this sequel, which stinks.
- It doesn't acknowledge your relationship from the original. (Which I completely understand would be a lot to ask, it just throws my head-canon off a bit when Makoto seems to forget we were dating.)
- There is one particular achievement to max out all of the BOND skills... which is insanely grindy, and dissuades me from 100%'ing the game. All the other achievements are really fair, but this one is just horrible. 
- You get overpowered rather quickly after the first jail, I never really had to decide which character to spend money on. I could simply just buy everyone the best weapon and armor the moment they became available. 
- You can tell the english dub had to record from their closets at home, so the audio levels are a bit off sometimes. 

A couple of spoiler-free tips:
- Upgrade the Bondmaker skill as soon as it is available.
- Unlock all the party members Master Arts ASAP. They are fun to use, and don't take much effort to unlock.
- Make sure you google how to get your game looking nice. The default settings really don't look that good. You don't have to mod, you just need to make a couple changes.

833.content:
Persona 5 Strikers was exactly what I wanted in an action Persona game. It faithfully implements mechanics from the rest of the series in an action combat form. If you play on hard mode, it's a significant challenge and much more fun, as you have to pay attention to what skills the enemies are using on screen.

You probably should play Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal first, as there's a lot of references to it that you might miss. You also won't have context on who all these characters are, as the game seems to expect you to know them already for the most part.

You might think with Koei Tecmo/Omega Force's involvement in development, that this is a musou/warriors game. It is definitely not. It's an action RPG. There are only mini-hordes of enemies, and you actually have to watch what all the little enemies are doing, as the skills they use can cripple you in an instant. You initiate combat on shadows walking around, that burst into multiple enemies. You want to try to be stealthy so you do not end up in a fight you can't win, as well as raising security level in the Jail.

If you like Persona games (or even Shin Megami Tensei games), I highly recommend checking this out. The story can be a bit nonsense sometimes, but is fun nonetheless. There is no calendar time slot system like in Persona 5. The calendar only moves on with certain story events. You can enter and exit dungeons all you want, and the day will still stay the same.

838.content:
Strikers is a beautiful blend of the JRPG and Musuo genres, taking the tight action and combo oriented gameplay of a Musuo and laying it over top a traditional dungeon crawling Persona title. The story is well written, and feels like a true successor to the ORIGINAL Persona 5.

 With no references to Royal, due to the different teams in different studios working on these games side by side, it leaves itself open to, potentially, DLC. I would hope for it, but it's doubtful as the game has already been out in Japan for a year without any mention of DLC. It's a fantastic game, if you're a Persona fan, don't let the idea of the combat turn you off, it's executed very well, and more in line with a Persona game that's taking queues from action titles than it does something like Dynasty Warriors.

The Phantom Thieves are back, and they've never felt more agile or more stylish, and they're ready to steal your heart once more.

849.content:
I like Warrior games and I like Persona so I'm sure this game is cool and all but this port is just so awful. 

Sometimes the game just wont boot unless I restart my PC, then once it does play, it can randomly crash to which I will have to restart my PC again to get the game to boot, and the game has terrible aliasing even with AA on, but with AA on all the UI gets super distorted on the edges, including text. I'm running this game off of an NVME SSD that loads other Triple A games in seconds, but this game legitimately takes minutes to load everytime I see a loading screen. 

This game is also way more difficult to run that it should be. At 2560x1440 on a GTX1080 with a Ryzen 9 3900x, I can not play this game at a locked 60fps even at low settings. For comparison, I am able to play Monster Hunter World at mid-high settings at a locked 60fps at 3440x1440. There's also no uncapped framerate option, no ultrawide support, the rendering resolution scale doesn't do anything for me, there are barely any graphical setting tweaks and overall this port is a mess. But that's just a Koei Techmo game for you. I hope ATLUS will do better going forward because Persona 4 Golden was pretty well done, but that was also a PS Vita remake of a PS2 port.

854.content:
Game initially was a good homage to Persona 5 but soon became apparent it was not going to follow well in its footsteps. The game starts of strong with a strong opening and good display of the mechanics and gameplay but as you progress through the game you realise it is just a dynasty game. 

Unfortunately the game lacks substance. Its all combat oriented but even that is shoddy at best. The story within this game is extremely lack-lustre compared to its predecessors. The amount of actual story in this game is questionable at best. With the removal of confidants and making dialogue scenes more and more scarce there is no actual character development.

The game is also bugged. Even on a good rig the game still runs slowly and at one point the 
game would soft lock you from continuing. To remedy this I had to try multiple methods that were convoluted just to progress. The gameplay at times can also feel clunky as its lock on camera and obstacles make it so that you character doesn't move freely or how you want.

Overall the game isn't worth the price tag. Get it on sale. Or just play Royal. It has the content of a side story not a sequel so it is far overpriced. Overall if the bugs were fixed the story is just compelling enough for a P5 fan to want to play but it is not worthy of being a sequel as it lacks the substance Persona 5 had.

The sequel to persona 5 (Royal), As a PC only player I never got to play royal but I have played Persona 3, 4 and 5. The games are a gift. They are spectacularly flashy, great characters and great turn-based combat. This one is different. It is a Warriors/Musou game. This entail huge battles and being overloaded by enemies. All in all its a stellar sequel to persona 5 and a great standalone action experience. If you've played persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal it is a must buy.

More Persona 5 is what I need in my life. And Atlus was happy to oblige. And that makes me happy.

This is probably a horrible place to start of with Persona. Go play P5 if you want to do that, then come back here. Or go play P4 on Steam if you don't have a Playstation. There are a lot of injokes and character specific stuff that'll woosh right past you if you haven't played P5 beforehand, and while the gameplay is pretty good, that's almost certainly not why most people want to play this. But if you have played P5, you know why you want to play this, and it will not disappoint.

I'm surprised how well the Persona 5 style was integrated into the hack and slash genre. It really does feel like a Persona game first and a musou game second. Not to mention that it's on Steam and the port is even pretty good! The only other thing I really could ask for is this fitting with Royal better, since this really is a follow-up from P5 and not P5R, but given how Atlus chose to develop both of these games, that wasn't really doable. 885.content:
Important note that this is SEQUEL to Persona 5 and should not be your jumping on point for the series. You should play and beat either Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal before playing this in order to not spoil yourself on characters and events, the game assumes you have beaten that game. 

To sum it up briefly, Strikers takes all the trappings from P5 and mixes in a battle system that feels like an Action-RPG in a musou's trench coat, in which you need to pay attention to weaknesses and strengths of both your team and your enemy. The game runs incredibly smooth as well, though it seems to have a 60 fps cap if that matters at all to anyone. The plot even follows a similar progression to the main game, so it can also be host to bout of nostalgia if it's been a while since you originally danced with the Phantom Thieves.  Most of the time management mechanics have been removed and you don't need to worry about hustling or figuring out who is the best to spend your time with. There are still moments where you can miss limited time items or side requests if you push on ahead without completing them. You can exit and enter dungeons without penalty and are otherwise encouraged to do so to replenish your HP and SP. Combos feel really good and even incorporate Persona skills, so you always have an avenue to attack enemy weaknesses. All the new characters are also great additions as well, and mesh well with the returning cast. 

30 hours in, I can still say that it should provide any P5 fans both a new and familiar experience, and it stands as probably one of my favorite Musou games, based on both the quality of the writing and the fantastic combat.

896.content:
If you're already a fan of Persona 5 and you're itching for more, this title is worth your time.

This title oozes with the same style and poise that Persona 5 has. The Dynasty Warriors combat mechanics work surprisingly well with the Persona conventions you're used to, so adjusting to this gameplay style is easier than you think. Each character is interesting and fun to play with in their own way, and you're properly incentivized to use all of them in different compositions throughout the game.

Aside from the combat, the rest of the game is familiar territory: Good story, great voice acting and character dynamics, excellent new music (and fantastic mixes on existing tracks), and a few cool surprises. Despite its nature as a genre and studio crossover, this is a genuine Persona game.

If you're [i] not [/i] a Persona fan already, this one might be a difficult game to sell you on. It's a follow-up with a very involved story that demands knowledge of the original to fully understand. If you don't have access to Persona 5, I would greatly recommend holding off until you play that masterpiece (let's hope they port it to PC). This is a sequel and better experienced after the original; it is not a standalone game.

I don't really have much to criticize here. The only minor complaint I had at all was about the frequency of tutorial interrupts toward the beginning of the game. If you're already familiar with the Persona conventions, there should be an option to prevent or skip those kind of pop-ups and show only the ones relevant to new mechanics like the combat. Especially since the majority of players of this game are likely Persona vets.

903.content:
I really liked Persona 4 Golden, I played it for 50 hours in 2015.
I loved Persona 5, I played it for 120 hours back in 2016.
I loved Persona 5 Royal, I played it for 100 hours in 2020.
Persona 5 Strikers is okay.

It's worth saying I do not like JRPG combat, and I'm also not a fan of hack and slash / Dynasty Warriors combat. What I love about Persona was the stories and life-sim aspects, and to a lesser extent the style the series just oozes at all times. Which, unfortunately, Persona 5 Strikers does lack in - there is no real life-sim aspect, and it still has style to it though perhaps not as much as the game it was based off of, but the story is still there and in full force - very enjoyable

I do think that Strikers is quite difficult compared to its mainline entry, but that comes with the territory of an action-based vs. turn-based game. Since I'm not interested, I played on easy, and I still find that Strikers is too difficult for my liking. I know, I know, get good, but again - not my cup of tea, I'm here for the story.

Perhaps my biggest complaint is an intermittent crashing. My first 8 hours or so were fine, but the next few have seen a number of frustrating crashes... I really don't want to have to play parts over and over again, but I find myself needing to. 

Overall though, want more Persona? Here you go. Enjoy.

924.content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a Dynasty Warriors game. If you're into that, then you'll like this game. THOUGH, nothing on this page will tell you that. BUT as soon as I saw the Koie Tecmo logo followed by Omega Force, I got a sneaking suspicion this was a Dynasty Warriors game. THOUGH, as someone who's only played a handful of these and 3 of their off shoots (including this one), I kind of like this one the best. Yeah, you can button mash, but this and Hyrule Warriors was better at forcing other actions. I've played Persona 5 for a few seconds, but got SUPER bored with how story heavy it is, and how awful the story is, this has a bit too much for me. It's a neat and faithful melding of Persona and the DW formula. Visually this is the best Dynasty Warriors has ever looked. Clear that Sega/Atlus seem to be very protective of this property and were very hands on with it. 

If you like Dynasty Warriors and Persona then this will definitely scratch that itch. I'll stick around for the battles, and just blow through the story, even though I know from previous attempts of getting into this series (P4 Golden) it means I'll probably get a bad ending, oh well. I'll look up an FAQ if the alternative endings are better or if it prolongs the GAME play. I like it. 3.5 out of 5 for me.

953.content:
This game is a really work of art, and a perfect fusion of RPG and Musou gameplay. If you have been wanting more Persona 5 writing, I would most certainly come to Persona 5 Strikers. While the turn based combat has left the scene, real time hack and slash combat fuses with the beloved Megaten mechanics to create a truly electrifying party. 

Coupled with amazing remixes of past P5 songs and the same characters you know and love, Strikers is a game that is hard *not* to recommend. The writing is some of the best ever put in a Megaten game, and there are so many improvements compared to Persona 5, such as UI refreshes, lighting overhauls, superior texture work, and many other additions.

Persona fans and Musou fans will feel very much at home here. I am loving this game, and glad it has come to me in such a low time for the entire world. It is a ray of sunshine in a ever so gloomy and cloudy year.

957.content:
The game plays and feels really good. The charcters and music are as amazing as the original Persona 5. 
This game has one problem tho. It keeps crashing. In around 18 hours of gameplay it happened 3 times. I lost around 2-3 hours re-doing stuff I already did because my game crashed. It really disrupts the flow of an otherwise really cool story and gameplay. 
There is no autosave, which was understandable in the original game with its playstyle, but here (in a game where you can get in and out of the jails with no repercussions whatsoever on time management AND get refills for hp and sp for the entire party) is just dumb. 
The crashes are a big problem that needs to be solved, but it would have been a tad bit better with an autosave function. Again, the game is good, but this is a major problem that needs to be a priority for the development team in a future patch (that needs to come ASAP).

961.content:
Let me start off by saying that I'm a huge Persona 5 fan, having played the base game several times and Royal twice. I went in to this game only seeing the trailers when they first came out. I'm not big on games similar to Dynasty Warriors, but I still feel like the gameplay was fairly enjoyable for the most part. My biggest issue comes from the story. Sometimes the story can feel touching, but other times it feels so bland and generic. Dialogue got SUPER REPETITIVE, by the end of the game I was skipping parts of the dialogue because it was unnecessary filler. The crashing was also a bit of an issue I had, but it was pretty minor. It only crashed like 4-5 times during my playthrough, so just make sure to save often just in case.

Characters-
Since this game follows the events of Persona 5, the characters are something I need to talk about. They had their moments, but they felt nothing like the characters from P5. They all felt a bit 1-dimensional at times, like they had a single character trait and that was it. They ended up feeling more like cardboard cutouts than actual characters. Even some of the new characters fall into this troupe, some more than others. I will say that I enjoyed Zenkichi and Sophia quite a bit in this game. Zenkichi and Sophia almost always had meaningful dialogue that added to their character or those around them. Even though the characters can feel stale at times, some of them had their moments that made me smile or laugh. 

Recommendation-
I don't recommend it, but I'm not entirely against it either. 

I would only recommend this game if you:
-Are a big fan of P5 or the Persona franchise as a whole
-Aren't playing for an immersive story(at least on the level of P5)
-Are a fan of the Dynasty Warrior genre
-Don't mind repetitive dialogue/gameplay
-Just want to play it for the gameplay/characters
-Just want to try it for yourself

974.content:
I absolutely reccommend this game.  It's insane how much this feels like the original Persona 5.  With a few exceptions, the entire game feels exactly like the first game did; menus, dungeons, boss designs...  It's incredible.  I was expecting a musou game more in-line with the others I've played; Hyrule and Fire Emblem Warriors.  Gone are the big battlefields of those games, replaced with small, tighter skirmishes that fit this sort of game better.

This game would be nearly perfect in my eyes, except for one thing: Denuvo.  Denuvo made my game crash more than a handful of times.  It was a serious drag each time I had to reload and go back sometimes to upwards of an hour.  Sega needs to remove it from the Steam version ASAP.  I had a friend who gave me a launcher without Denuvo, and in those last few hours of gameplay, not only did the game run better and load faster, but it didn't crash once.  

That aside, if you liked Persona 5, absolutely give this game a shot.  It was the sequel I didn't know I could have.
