991.content:
With most of the negative reviews focusing entirely on the technical issues with the game, I figure I'll complain about the game itself just to shake things up a bit. There will be unmarked spoilers.

[b] TL;DR: [/b] Consider this more of a "meh" review. If you just wanna see the gang get back together for a demon-slaying road-trip, are willing to be even more fragile than the Demi-Fiend at the start of Nocturne, and don't mind bosses with insane HP values, it's stylish like Persona 5 always has been and may be worth picking up. YMMV with the story. Also, Futaba makes cute noises when you enter the system menu. This is very important.

[b] Gameplay:[/b] Having tried Normal and Hard difficulty settings, it feels all over the place so far. Both incoming and outgoing damage fluctuates on a per-fight basis between being crushed by a black hole (dying/killing in 2-3 hits) or being slapped by a wet noodle, even when exploiting weaknesses. Taking advantage of persona resistances seems to work, but nothing will save your braindead AI companions from standing in pools of whatever element they're weak to and dying/wasting SP on healing. 

It sucks because the most effective way to take down a boss, assuming you don't want to waste twenty minutes whittling it down while it endlessly spawns additional demons, is to stand still, open the command menu so time freezes, switch to a Persona that can exploit its weaknesses, and spam attacks, maybe switching to another character when you run out of SP. 

This is almost necessary because bosses have an obscene amount of HP, and spamming attacks from the menu deals damage far faster than trying to use the free, reduced-strength spells from combos. It also has the side effect of practically guaranteeing you're not getting hit by anything while trying to pull off said combos, which feels really cheap.


[b] Story: [/b] I haven't finished the game yet, but so far the stakes are at an all-time low for the Phantom Thieves. The first target was acceptable since she went out of her way to abuse some innocent people, but the second target in particular had me rolling my eyes; as far as I can tell, his only "crime" was not admitting that his novels were hot garbage that only sold well because his editors manipulated him and hyped up his status as the grandson of a famous writer. There was a claim about him plagiarizing, but he wouldn't be the first popular author to do just that and get away with it.

Forcing that kid to go on live television and "confess" to the heinous crime of being manipulated into writing bad novels had me in stitches. At best, it felt like petty revenge for something that happens all the time IRL in all kinds of media. At worst, it could have no lasting effect; realistically all the company would need to do is throw a few employees under the bus along with the kid in some kind of apology letter, wait a few months, and then the public would forget all about it.

In short, it's a far cry from changing the hearts of the people from Persona 5. Stopping a teacher from preying on students and driving them to suicide? I'm down, no question. 

Stopping a famous idol from abusing the people around her? Sure, I guess. 

Stopping a writer from writing bad novels?
 
...

Who gives a shit?

1078.content:
Having finally finished Persona 5 after playing through it for six months, I decided to hop onto Persona 5 Strikers as soon as I finished. I can't say I have anything substantial to say about it yet, I'm only an hour in and god knows that these games go on forever. What I can give are general impressions that might influence otherwise prying eyes:

- Do I recommend this if you haven't played Persona 5 yet? So far, no. Do I think it's a requirement, though? Also no. The general impression I've gotten so far is that if you haven't had the chance to play P5 yet, it'll be weird hopping into this story with all of these characters you haven't met yet, but if you really don't have any choice, you'll make do.
- If you HAVE played P5, you'll notice that this takes some pretty big departures from what was in that game. Most notably in the combat, which is this game's main selling point, but the area that I think will be the most contentious is that there isn't any Social Link system. P5S is a lot more linear than its predecessor. I don't think that's a bad thing, necessarily; there's so much to do in P5 that I'd happily start a new game if one hundred more hours didn't seem daunting to me. But, if that's what you really loved P5 for, it's best that you set your expectations at the gate before stepping into Strikers. This is a spin-off that acts as a semi-sequel of sorts, but no, I wouldn't call it a full-on sequel.
- The combat is what will make or break this for you. As I said, it's the main selling point and they've stripped out all of the non-linear segments from the original game to focus on it. From what I've played so far, it's pretty typical of a Musou fighter. There's a billion enemies on screen, you have your teammates on the  side, go beat the shit out of everything that you see. They did implement some of Persona's systems, in that you do still have your gun and can cast your Persona onto enemies who might have elemental weaknesses. That's cool, but it doesn't seem very deep so far. Again, these are impressions.
- Other than the combat and lack of the Social Link system, they've managed to maintain the Persona 5 style down to a tee. You have your animated cutscenes, fantastic score, cell-shaded art style, all the way down to the way conversations play out. Pretty impressive, seeing as I was expecting this to just be beating the shit out of everyone on screen.
- The PC for this is... okay? It's not bad, and minus some crashing issues that have been reported, it runs well. If you're going to play this on PC, though, keep a controller on hand. You can rebind the controls, which is neat seeing as the default control scheme borders on being decent to "who the fuck thought this layout made any sense at all?", but it really just works better with a controller.

I hope to write a fully fledged review when I'm done with this, too.

Also, Atlus: [i]bring Persona 5 to PC[/i]. If not Royal, then at least bring the original version over? Like, I get that you're still trying to test the waters and it'll take a little while to optimize your engine to run on PC, that's okay. But releasing the semi-sequel to a game that's exclusive to one platform and having it being a multi-plat title before the original game gets ported to anything else is just kind of funny to me.

1079.content:
I recommend this game but it is more of a cautionary one.

*Persona 5 Strikers is a sequel to the original Persona 5. It is not exactly a sequel to Persona 5 Royal – the expanded version released later. So Royal exclusive characters are not present in this game nor are the events of its third semester are covered. Persona 5 Strikers’ release on Steam is admittedly rather strange considering that neither the original Persona 5 or the Royal version are not present on the platform, so new PC players are likely to be confused and would spoil the events of the original game.

I have seen some players say that you do not need to play the original game but that is not true at all. It is highly recommended that you should play, at least, the original Persona 5 before Persona 5 Strikers either on PS4 or by waiting for a Steam release if that happens.*

I really enjoyed the story of this sequel. Most Persona spin offs have rather tepid stories but this one pulls its weight above the others. The road trip setup is a great idea and it all helps solidify the fact that the Phantom Thieves are a close set of friends overall. It’s also quite funny and entertaining overall. I also enjoyed the new characters – Zenkichi and Sophia – and thought they fitted in well with the story and the Phantom Thieves’ road trip as well. But sightseeing is unfortunately limited and you feel like you’re in the Metaverse more than the locations you visit. Additionally, whilst the bond system is competent and makes sense in the context of the story it cannot replace the freedom of the confidant system from the original game (returning players may be disappointed with the lack of returning side characters from P5 as well, although it would be a stretch to involve them in this story). The result is a far more linear, repetitive, and straightforward journey. (On a side note I found that some plot elements from previous games were repeating in P5 Strikers, not just jokes but also character backstories as well – quite distracting for those familiar with the main games and I hope that fresh plot details are explored for the next inevitable numbered sequel.)

P5 Strikers’ gameplay is designed to be like an arcade like experience. Within the Metaverse combat has been changed from turn based battles into Dynasty Warriors real time combat where you face many enemies at once. The change from turn based to real time combat works surprisingly well and fits naturally for a spin-off title. It can get repetitive and grindy but for the most part it was fun. Persona fusion also returns but it is scaled down in comparison to the original and does not have the depth previous seen in prior games. But it’s all in service for this arcade gameplay and as I said previously it works well and it is fun to play. 

The game also successfully adapts Persona 5's graphical style and music. The new music in this game is really good and effortlessly reaches the same standards of the original game and the Royal version.

I never really had a major issue with any of the game’s mechanics, story, or characters. But the most severe issues are the technical problems and the state of the port. Reviewers and posts on the Steam discussion page report have constantly reported the infinite loading screen and crashing bugs. I have experienced it as well. I was prevented from playing the game for about a week since it refused to load the main menu in full screen or borderless mode. Only opening the game in windowed mode worked but I got frame drops and it was not smooth. I only managed to get around these loading screen crashes when I saw a post on the Steam Discussion that recommended disabling the additional content that contained the behind the scenes and interviews for the game. Apparently there was an issue in the content that carried over into the main game that caused the severe crashing. After disabling it I managed to load the game and play it in a more stable state. Whoever that person was who recommended disabling that – may Philemon bless you because you saved my play through.

However, that was not the end of my issues playing the game. Whilst I never experienced the boss crashes that prevent you from advancing I still experienced crashes when transitioning to a new area or whilst in a loading screen although it never repeats this behaviour constantly. I also experienced stuttering during the in-game and anime cut scenes but perhaps the most annoying bug I had experienced was the severe frame drops and the resolution glitch. Sometimes I would have severe unexplained frame drops despite being at the game’s highest settings at 1080p for the majority of my play through. When I changed the settings and reset them the game looked more pixilated and blurry despite, again, being at high settings. It was a frustrating issue and I only managed to solve it by playing around with the render quality function which makes me think there is a bug associated with the option.

I also experienced some inconsistent issues regarding the English voice acting as well. The English voice acting is rather good so there is no issue regarding the actors themselves. It’s just some characters sound quiet against the background music and I had to change the sound settings just so that I can hear them. I had this problem more so with Yusuke and Zenkichi. This is an impact of the pandemic since these actors most likely worked at home where they probably did not have the best sound mixing equipment.

(I should mention that some people may not have encountered any issues at all and that this experience is not universal for everyone.)

This port is a mess and desperately needs to be patched. But we are a month after release and Atlus have not released one – only a Beta Branch. After the initial issues regarding the PC ports of Catherine and Persona 4 Golden they cannot keep releasing games like this on Steam on day 1 and remain silent on official fixes until they happen, whether its future games or ports of older games. It’s quite frustrating. It does not help that people begging for more Persona on Steam drown out the concerns made about the bugs and issues with the port.

What we are left with is a game that is really fun to play with a stellar story and great additional characters that are welcome in the world of Persona 5. It is likely the best spin-off yet for the franchise. But at the same time my playthrough on PC was unstable and prone to technical problems. This is why I give Persona 5 Strikers a cautionary recommendation because the fun I had playing the game managed to outshine the quality of the port and I managed to look past it. Whilst I managed to play through the game, for those who want the game but haven’t purchased it on Steam yet I would wait until it is patched and the main issues are resolved. I know it is bad to wait on a game to be patched when we all waited for over a year for this game to be localised into English, but hopefully it will be worth it.

(This review may be changed or removed if a patch is released.)

1084.content:
Persona 5 Strikers The Review

Played On: PC (Steam)
Completed Date: 3/17/2021
Playtime: 72.5 hours

Status: Completed 100%.  

Persona 5 Strikers is a direct sequel to the story of Persona 5 (not Persona 5 Royal) and follows the same loveable crew on a road trip journey. It uses a new hack and slash action RPG combat inspired in part by Musuo games like Dynasty Warriors but is still ostensibly Persona.

Graphics [80/100]:
The graphics of Persona 5 Strikers follows the same style of the main entry using the stylized cel shading graphics. These graphics pop and look great.  They ooze style and feel unique.  Strikers is a bit more colorful compared to the original.  The overall package is fantastic and well thought out.  If you liked the style of Persona 5 or anime in general you will enjoy this as it is more of the same.  

Battle System / Combat / Core Gameplay [92/100]:
The battle system in Persona 5 Strikers is a massive departure from the original.  It is no longer a turn based JRPG game but now it is an action based hack and slash that uses the ideas from the Persona world. That said, combat is fantastic and fun. It is both fast paced and strategic as you have to abuse the system, as any good Persona game would have you do, to beat the mini bosses and bosses since they have large health pools. The difference is you have to dodge and move and input commands as you go. When it came down to it I found this all very fun and all of the characters have unique and different play styles that made for a fun and challenging game. The game does abandon most of the outside of combat gameplay from the original game which keeps the game moving steady but you do miss social links for sure.

 Audio [75/100]:
The voice acting and music is good. Voice acting is top notch and everyone nails it in the English dub. The music is also good but lacks some of the best songs from the original. It still has the feels but with the missing songs it doesn’t quite have the same pizzaz that the original brought. I still enjoyed it.  

Controls [71/100]:
Controls are responsive for the most part. There is a slight delay whenever you open a menu that you must wait out prior to doing things but it’s easy to become used to that. All the menus are animated so it’s not bad having to wait a second. Characters can feel a bit loose when running but I got used to it quickly enough.

Story [82/100]:
The story in Persona 5 Strikers follows after the original game and while this story isn’t quite as good it still brings it. We get extended time with the entire crew as we go on a road trip and this is a great experience and I find that this group fits incredibly well with this format. We begin unraveling the metaverse yet again and from there the story unfolds and the intricacies can be found and present themselves very well.

Extras [60/100]:
The side quests (requests) are almost entirely go collect something or go kill something. These can be fun since some of the kill quests are pretty challenging and the rewards are good. There are occasional quests to explore parts of the dungeon without porting or getting spotted and these are different and fun as well.  As a whole though the side quests offer little story or interesting add ons outside of challenge and good rewards. 

Overall [87/100]:
Persona 5 Strikers is a fantastic game that has a combat system that is fun and engaging while being simple and flashy as well. The story is good and interesting and the characters are still as fantastic as ever. If you are a fan of Persona 5 this is a must play. For others as this is a direct sequel I would recommend Persona 5 first then this. If you didn’t like Persona 5 this plays so differently that you may still like it as long as it wasn’t the aesthetics that you didn’t enjoy.

1111.content:
Persona 5 Strikers has been in my opinion, one of the best spin offs of the persona series yet. Lets begin this by saying that while you can play this without ever having played persona 5 or persona 5 royal, the game expects you have and all character development is saved for the new comers, Sophia and Zenkichi. With that out of the way, lets start with the pros to the game.

The graphics, while not as impressive as the original game, still have the p5 charm to it and the overall art style has seen great improvements in my opinion.

The new tracks like Counterstrike and Axe to Grind as well as the remixes of Last Surprise and Rivers in the Desert make the OST of this game a win in my book, with a overall feeling of high energy in each track.

The gameplay (once you get used to the controls) is extremely fun, with persona elements such as weaknesses and all out attacks incorporated nicely into the new format. Since this is what you're going to be spending the entire game doing, it does good work to not get stale.

The story is basically p5's story but with the villains being much more fleshed out and relatable. It also does have a few elements that make it fresh but for the most part it's a lot of the same.

The voice work and dialogue is surprisingly good and had a few solid chuckles, with Zenkichi, Ryuji, Futaba and Sophia taking the spotlight throughout the game.

Now that that's done, some somewhat nit picky negatives.

Playing on a keyboard is not advised as the controls are somewhat awkward and require some switching around to make work.

Options for 4k resolution are simply not here for those who have such moniters.

I found that the game can be rather buggy at times. I had multiple instances where buttons would just stop working, such as my attack button or the enter and escape keys. This would require me to halt all progress so i could restart my game in order to fix it. The game also crashed twice on me.

Finally, your characters don't level up with at the same rate as they do p5, meaning that your main party could be level 60 while the characters you haven't used at all could be level 44. This isn't a major problem until the final boss where a certain feature requires you use all your party members. And if you haven't leveled up all your members equally, then it's time to hit the grind stone for a few hours so can actually stand a chance.

Overall, these negatives didn't do much in the way of harming the overall experience. I thoroughly enjoyed strikers and recommend to anyone who's a fan of the persona series. It's well worth the money and a good way to kill 35+ hours.

Overall I really recommend this game if you're a fan of Persona 5 or the Persona series

1167.content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a sequel to the original Persona 5 (You kinda have to ignore the new additions of P5R, sorry Kasumi!)
Storywise the game is so good and actually surprised me since I didn't expect a good story at all! 
But I don't want to talk a single thing about the story even if they won't be considered as spoilers because it's the best if you enter the game blindly! But also the game needs the player to know one thing and another about the phantom thieves, some other characters, persona aspects, etc. It's not 100% necessary tho but trust me you can't understand/enjoy much of the story if it is your first ever persona game! 
Many people think that Persona 5 strikers is a Dynasty Warriors game with a persona theme but nope, it's much more like a real-time action Jrpg than that.
The combat system is not turn-based anymore,instead it features real-time combo based combat which is a new&cool experience IMO. For me the combat was starting to get boring and smash button like in the first jail of the game but then I changed the difficulty to hard and also the game introduced more challenging enemies, so if you don't want to feel the same play on high or at least medium difficulty and also don't ignore dire shadows.
The combat is pretty enjoyable and a nice addition to the old turn-based combat system.
Many main factors of P5 or persona series in general are removed or been cut down in Persona 5 strikers such as Velvet room, Social links, daily calender system, and many other stuff that are all simplified/removed. 
Overall, P5 strikers is a must play for P5 fans who couldn't wait to see phantom thieves again! but if you haven't played P5 yet or even any other persona games and also if you can't get along with the new simplified aspects of the game,then you should probably ignore the game/wait for sales.

Now please keep bringing persona games to steam Atlus!

1170.content:
Persona 5 Strikers is not exactly what i was expecting, when this game was first announced it just looked a musou/warriors spin-off game. However after playing it, it does feel more like an Action-RPG than a Musou game.

Persona 5 Strikers in terms of gameplay and story does feel like a true sequel to the original Persona 5. It's gameplay feels like Persona 5's but translated faithfully into an Action-RPG, whenever you encounter enemies instead of transitioning into a turn based-RPG battle, in Strikers it smoothly starts a small Action-RPG/Musou skirmish. The battle system from Persona 5 is actually still sort of present in this game as most of the Persona skills are in this game and work very similarly.

There is Persona fusion in this game, while it does feel simplified it does feel fun and useful.

Every party member in this game has a very unique playstyle and is fun to play, it is fun to try out each character and switch up your party trying to find good combinations.

The Story of Persona 5 Strikers, while i don't think its as strong as the original's story, it still does a lot that I like and has some very strong moments. Also this game feels like a real journey as you go to so many different locations. It's a real change of pace for Persona. Also the chemistry of characters in this game is quite enjoyable.

Also the new characters introduced in this game are quite likeable, perhaps some of my favourites in the series.

Also I must mention the soundtrack. It's Persona. It's a complete banger. 
 
Now to talk about performance and quality of this PC port.
In my experience it's been pretty good, I have had about four or five crashes, however I never lost any progress from them as I saved my progress every time I had the option. When this game crashes it is usually in a loading screen for a transition so be careful and save.

Also this game lacks 144hz support which is a shame, it also lacks options to set the level of anti-aliasing, you can only choose for it to be on or off. In 1080p the AA looks pretty bad. However if you are able to run this game with rendering scale 2.0 then do that as it will drastically help remedy the AA. 

I played this whole game on Mouse and Keyboard, it is actually pretty fun, moving the camera with my mouse and using m1 and m2 for my attacks. Is it better than controller? 
Probably not, but I found it fun. I did need to remap some stuff however as  some of the default keybinds aren't the greatest. Also while remapping my keybinds I discovered that some binds must always be set on keyboard, which is kinda annoying.

Overall I enjoyed this game quite a bit, A great sequel to probably my favourite game of all time.

Hopefully we will get more Persona games on PC

1179.content:
[quote][h1]Full review (including score): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EuYTl-_t6ZI
Summarized review below![/h1][/quote]
Japan and releasing sequels on platforms that don’t have the original, name a more iconic duo. Regardless, at least ATLUS seems keen on bringing their games to more platforms, so I was excited to finally give Strikers a play.

[b]Note: Had to trim review to fit character limit, check video for full version![/b]

[h2]Combat:[/h2]
Unlike Persona 5, Strikers is co-developed with Omega Force, the studio most well-known for the Musou series. Strikers adopts that same kind of hack-and-slash gameplay, but with a bit of a Persona twist. For example, while you are still mowing down hordes of enemies at a time like in a Musou game, you’re also able to pause mid-combat to make use of your Persona skills. These skills have elemental traits and there are matchups with enemies that can cause you to do more or less damage dependent on their traits. In fact, you pretty much have to account for these matchups with bigger enemies as otherwise you’ll be merely tickling them.

[h2]Difficulty/Combat Feel:[/h2]
The combat difficulty can be a bit hit or miss. It’s always fun to blow through these massive groups of enemies with your big persona skills, but the boss fights can drag a bit – as all of them are effectively giant damage sponges. This is rooted in the combat’s lack of impact. You don’t really FEEL like you’re hitting most enemies or taking damage, you just kinda see it reflected on-screen. There’s little in the way of audio and visual feedback to really give the combat that sense of meatiness.

This is par for the course for a Musou game though, which I am a fan of by the way so I can’t say this was too unexpected, but I had at least hoped that a Persona crossover would have upped their game a bit.

[h2]Combat Depth:[/h2]
This is not your traditional Musou game where you can go in and just start swinging – there’s a lot more of a tactical emphasis this time around. The persona mechanic I mentioned earlier is easily the biggest change there. As Joker, you’re able to equip a set number of these personas and they can be customized, fused, and upgraded to your liking in the velvet room. It can get pretty complex there too – there’s a lot of fun to be had for those that enjoy min-maxing.

However, the combat also has an increased emphasis on movement. Not only are you going to have to make effective use of your dodge ability, but there’s also follow-up attacks that will have you zipping across the screen and a neat “phantom dash” mechanic that allows you to make use of the environment to do certain special attacks. And this is on top of the fact that you can swap to and from your different party members at any time – each with their own unique combat quirk. I had a lot of fun figuring out how each played and coming up with an optimal party, swapping members out occasionally to suit certain bosses and such.

[h2]Combat Cont.:[/h2]
You enter a new area, wipe the enemies, proceed to the next, and repeat all the way until the boss. It can feel a bit repetitive at times, but the added depth kept me interested enough to keep going – and again, this is all with a Persona twist, so you’ll get a lot of story scenes and such in-between. Some minor changes I would like to see are improvements to the ally AI and the ability to skip battle cutscenes. Seeing that flashy super move for the first few times? Great, but not the hundred or so times after that.

[h2]Level Design:[/h2]
Unfortunately, Strikers falls into that JRPG pitfall of having incredibly basic and oftentimes blocky levels. Hallways connecting square rooms, invisible walls everywhere, and crude use of the already limited movement abilities – it’s all there and unfortunate to see in what otherwise is a visually appealing game. The exploration of course takes a hit in the process. The blocky layout makes for much more linear levels and the chests and other hidden goodies are usually just down another hallway or in some other easily accessible location – there’s no sense of “wow, they actually hid a chest here?”

[h2]Story:[/h2]
If you liked the story in Persona 5, you will absolutely like the story here as well. It’s got the fun character interactions, the plot twists, the social commentary (even if heavy-handed), and some decent pacing backing it all up. It was nice to see the gang get back together for another adventure, one that quite literally has them traveling the country.

The plot follows a similar structure to the first game. The first few jails (this game's palaces) I was like – okay, this is basically the same thing as the first story – but it started to deviate as it went on and the differences between the palaces of the first game and the jails of Strikers became more apparent. Then, towards the end, it ramps up and becomes this much bigger thing – in classic Persona fashion.

[h2]Can I Play Without Playing the First?[/h2]
There’s no “catching up” here, Strikers just dumps you right into things expecting you to know all the characters and events from the first game. For those that have no knowledge of the story, there are a few options. Of course, the best would be to just play Persona 5 or Royal. However, as neither were ever released on PC, that might not be an option for many. The second would be to simply watch Persona 5 the Animation. I know fans like to dunk on it, but it’s honestly not that bad and will set you up perfectly to understand the story in Strikers. If neither of those work, well, you could just read or watch a summary, but that’s definitely not an approach I would recommend.

[h2]Graphics/Music:[/h2]
Right off the bat, it… doesn’t look any different from the original – so if you liked that look – well, nothing changed. The music on the other hand, that absolutely slaps. It did in Persona 5 and it does again with Strikers, adding a bunch of new music while also including some excellent remixes of tracks from the original.

[h2]PC Port:[/h2]
I won’t say it’s a bad port, but it’s far from great. The biggest disappointment comes in the fact that it is locked to 60 fps. That 60 fps is at least stable though, only dipping during loading screens where you can’t tell. Strikers also has higher resolution support, including 1440p (which I played at with no issues) and 4K.

I’ve seen a lot of posts describing constant crashing issues and infinite load screens, but the game only ever crashed on me once, and it was during a dialogue scene shortly after I saved, so nothing lost there. Regardless, this is something that I hope the devs look into, as any crashes at all is worth fixing. Otherwise the game ran flawlessly. I had no further bugs or technical issues of any kind.

[h2]Controls:[/h2]
I went with an Xbox One controller and had no issues aside from the lack of rumble, but I believe that to be a bug as it also affects PS4 controllers. On keyboard/mouse, the controls are functional (and can be remapped) but are not ideal. On mouse especially, there’s a permanent negative acceleration effect, where the faster you move the mouse, the slower the camera moves. There is at least mouse input in menus, but I would recommend a controller for this one.

[h2]Overall:[/h2]
Strikers is yet another nice addition to the series, offering up several changes of its own while staying true to what makes Persona great. There’s the interesting story with all its twists and turns, the fun characters with all their quirks, and the top-notch visual presentation and music on top of that. The combat has its ups and downs though, bringing more depth than what is usual for a Musou game, but bringing that genre’s problems along with it (particularly the lack of impact and damage sponging). Regardless, it’s still a fun time and a worthwhile experience if you want to see the story continued.

Follow my [b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/3215371]Steam Curator Page[/url][/b] for more reviews!

POST PATCH REVIEW 4/20/2021: It brings me great joy to finally update this review to a storngly recommended, as the newest patch has just released that appears to fix the crashing. I was able to play an additional 2 hours tonight with no crashing, and plan to do a second playthrough on NG+ soon. This game, despite appearances, is not a Warriors game and I mean that in the best way possible. Honestly, this game has no right being as good as it is but honestly it's incredible. Arguably a stronger game, emphasis on game, than the original Persona 5. They've refined nearly every aspect of the combat and Persona fusion systems, and cut a lot of the fat in the social interactions and day-to-day life elements of the game. This is a lean, mean, and extremely enjoyable Persona experience.

The game is also a surprisingly competent action game. I fully believe that a Level 1 playthrough would be possible based on pure skill alone, as every enemy and boss has clearly telegraphed attacks with unique projectile patterns that can all be evaded. The game never forces you to tank damage and heal like most action RPGs because the damage is unavoidable. With that said, it would be extremely tedious to do this because of how little damage you would be doing in return. However, I think it is an accomplishment in game design that I came away feeling this way.

I only have 3 genuine complaints. First, this game honestly is just "Persona 5 Again" in terms of its story. The only surprise you will find here is how blatant the plagarism is. Second, there seems to be a lot of tedious, repetitive, and grindy aspects to this game. However, we all play on PC here and Cheat Engine exists who ultimately you only need to suffer through this if you choose to. Finally, the god damned hooks in Okinawa. You either know what I mean or you will. It's just a terrible decision to make the player wait on this slow hooks in order to progress through the dungeon especially when the characters are clearly able to jump the height required. It's horrible.

I wholeheartedly recommended this game. It's a good deal even at full price, and a great experience for anyone who likes Persona or even Action RPGs.

ORIGINAL NEGATIVE REVIEW: This game is actually incredible, but I cannot give it a positive review until the random crashes are fixed. In my playtime, I have experienced nearly 2 dozen crashes and while with habitual saving the consequences can be mitigated it is extremely frustating. I shouldn't have to play in constant fear of random crashes, possibly even caused by the DRM. Until the crashing is resolved, don't buy this.

1188.content:
[h1]Persona 5 Strikers gives us a completely new experience from the developer's past games.[/h1]

48 hours and one game clear later, I [b]finally[/b] feel qualified to write a review.
I walked into Persona 5 Strikers thinking it was [b][i]yet another musou game.[/i][/b] I have never been so wrong about a video game in my entire life.

[h1][b]Omega Force[/b] changed the traditional [i]"Clear this area, go to outpost A, defeat enemy B" [/i]and crafted a new experience that made sure the game [i]remained[/i] a [b]Persona[/b] game before it is a [b]musou [/b]game.[/h1]

The combination of both a captivating story and involved button mashing combat (it makes sense if you think really hard about it) results in the [b][i]ENTIRE[/i][/b] Persona 5 Strikers experience.
I honestly thought I was going to open up this game and be put in a menu-based system where I had to select my destination to move from point A to point B. I didn't expect a well-written story, or lengthy, enjoyable cutscenes, and map areas that were more than just [i]"Go[/i][b][i] [/i][/b][i]here! Your ally is being attacked! Help x! Don't let y fall!"[/i]
If you look at all of the past musou games, they are all the same copy and pasted formula. Same map layouts, different textures and models. The only thing that's probably different in each one are the characters and stories. Persona 5 Strikers, by definition from experience, broke free from this category.
What the game has retained from Omega Force's past games was the combat system, and that's about it. We are granted an enhanced combat system that allows usage of Personas, Ambushes, and Phantom Dashes. The game is more of an Action RPG than it is a musou.

[h1]The game is more of an Action RPG than it is a musou.[/h1]

The story is incredible. The characters are incredible. The music is incredible.
We are allowed time outside of jails to do.. [i]Persona[/i] things. Our Personas level up, we play with their skills and passives, and we continue on.
The request system grants us access to new challenges that give us items and xp. Some of the requests pose more of a challenge than the main story, and the rewards are all the greater for it!

[h1]You are rewarded as you play.[/h1]

At a glance this can sound confusing. Most games have an ending point as far as content and unlockables about halfway through their playthrough. Even when you thought you unlocked everything and can just farm stuff, the game gives you [i]even more[/i] as you progress through the story; it never feels like it dries out, because the timing of everything you get is well placed throughout the key points of the game.

[h1]Aside from a few bugs, this game is a MUST play.[/h1]

I didn't finish the first palace of the original Persona 5. The game did not captivate me as much as Persona 4 Golden or this game did. But after playing this, I wouldn't mind playing the prequel game and treat it exactly as such. You can enjoy this game even if you haven't played the first game. It's definitely a new experience for the genre, and I highly recommend picking it up to see for yourself!

1192.content:
I'll try to go into some detail about why I don't recommend the game, but first I'll give a shorter version to be concise.

[h1]TL;DR:[/h1]

The game is reasonably fun, but the Warriors-style combat does not mix very well with the Persona aspects.
The subtle parts of writing, which the Persona series is well-known for, is missing almost entirely here.

Is this a [i]BAD[/i] game?
No, but I am forcing myself to complete it, vs. doing so because I enjoy it.

[h1]The Long Version[/h1]

I could ramble for a while, but while playing, I found myself consistently complaining to myself about several several issues, which other games (including games from both the Persona series, and the Warriors games) do better, which lower my overall enjoyment of the game.

* Persona-series influence on combat
* High-level structure of the game, and clashing elements

Before I go into some of these, I want to point out, there are other topics I [i]could[/i] talk about at length, but won't be. These include things ranging from plot issues (like barely acknowledging any fallout from Persona 5 original), to technical things (if you DPS bosses well enough and fast enough, it will overlap voice lines, and you often can't pay attention to them anyway because real-time boss fight).

Just know these are not exhaustive, they are just the largest issues I feel I can convey well.

[h2]Persona Mechanics + Combat[/h2]

This game features Warriors style combat. You know, huge crowds of enemies, relatively simple combos, flashy animations, lots of characters. All of that.

However, it [i]also[/i] makes use of aspects from the Persona series. Such as type-affinities, 1-More, All-Out-Attacks, and more.
The game reflects type weaknesses in a way that makes sense for Persona, but is less-than-idea for an action game; if you are fighting an enemy with a weakness, they generally have damage resistance against anything other than that weakness.

Mini-boss or "tough" enemies have this especially bad. They may only have ~200HP, but without hitting weaknesses, you will do chip damage (maybe 2-3 each hit).

This encourages you to use any attacks with that element, and not too much else. Attacks which don't affect weakness are often more risky than helpful, as you will commit to animations, which are doing chip damage, and leave you vulnerable (yes you can often dodge/dash-cancel out of these, but not 100% of the time).

This means that will often flail wildly between trivial, and a huge pain.
Because enemies either flinch from any attack, and have barely 20 HP, or they have boatloads of health, and Hyper-armour most things aside from their weaknesses.

[h2]High Level Structure[/h2]

The Persona series is mostly built around doing dungeon delves where you have to weight whether to keep going, and risk dying/failing, or retreat, and keep some progress, so you can get a full-heal and so some socializing to potentially get Social-Link/Confidant perks.

This game is not a normal Persona game, it's an action game. However, checkpoints are generally plentiful, you can mostly leave the dungeon/Jail whenever you want, and get a full heal + SP recovery. The only cost is loading/transition times.

This means that each miniboss or serious encounter has to be tough enough to be a threat to you from full HP & SP, or you could just get a full heal (similar to issue with Skyrim, Breath of the WIld, and similar "you can eat your inventory" games).

Is this necessarily a problem? I... don't know?
It certainly feels off; if you can leave and heal pretty much for free, is there really any pressure to keep going further than a single checkpoint distance? Are there any benefits?
Because a player may wish to keep going, and not leave after literally every single fight, the game includes many fights which, even at-level, are an ambush + all-out-attack (essentially 2 button presses) away from clearing a fight.

So why have those? Why not just have the more significant/noteworthy fights be dangerous, and full-heal the player after winning each? After all, they can already do that, but would have to wait through loading screens.

Overall, this back-and-forth makes the game pretty tedious.

[hr][/hr]

Regardless of these thoughts, if you enjoy the game, awesome. I don't think this game is abhorrent.

I just find myself wishing I'd stop and replay Persona 5 Royal again.

I figured that if that was the case, "Not Recommended" was the closest to my feelings, and I owed it to others to leave a review.

1217.content:
If you liked P5 you're probably going to like this game too.

Combat is simple yet incredibly fun. Showtimes and All-Out Attacks are hype af

Story is more linear than the original game but the cast is as enjoyable as ever. Voice acting for the English version is mostly excellent, despite the difficulties they had recording during the pandemic.

Persona fusing has been simplified with less options, which has in turn made that part of the game less enjoyable than mainline persona games. There are also less personas to fuse and collect in total.

The game also suffers a bit from having unbalanced difficulty scaling. It goes from being somewhat challenging in the beginning, to becoming quite easy in the end due to increased HP and SP resources. Merciless difficulty fixes this a bit in NG+, with the consequence of making minibosses too tanky.

But overall I would say that Koei Tecmo has done a great job implementing turn-based RPG elements into an Action RPG. All in all a worthy sequel to P5.

1226.content:
I might have only 18 hrs of playtime until now but as someone who has spend multiple hundreds of hours into the original base game of Persona 5, I can say for certain that this is a love letter to everyone who has played the base Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal.

[h1] Story (without major spoilers) [/h1]

After the events of the main game, the protagonist returns to Tokyo for a visit after he was away for half a year. He and the rest of his Friends decided to go camping after they've got reunited. 
While they were gathering equipment for that camping trip, they stumbled across the metaverse yet again but this time, it's used to steal the desires from innocent people to affect them in the real world. 
The Phantom Thieves of hearts are back from their hiatus and ready to get those stolen desires back!

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

Unlike the other persona spin-offs that were either turn based (like the main games) or 2d fighting games, this one is actually a hack and slay with persona traits in it like: 
weakness and resist, all out attacks, 1 more, debuffs and buffs, baton pass, the third eye, ambush and of course the ability to switch personas via wildcard (which is Joker). 
But they also added many new things that are quite interesting like: 
bonds, master arts, showtimes, gaining personas by random drops, being able to use surroundings as an advantage and so on.
The dungeon crawling is also a big part of this game, so be prepared to slice through countless enemies while exploring the cognitive world!    

[h1] Music [/h1]

What is there more to say? If you have played the main game, then you know every single persona Ost is a bop and this time it's no exception.

Yearning to hear some good old Persona classics come back, like "rivers in the desert" ? Fear not, this game won't let you down. 
You want "last surprise" but more funky? Here you go buddy!
You want new Osts that slap ass? Well with axe to grind and daredevil, there's nothing you can do wrong. 
Through the Legacy BGM Dlc which is available through the deluxe edition, it is also possible to change the Battle theme to another one of the previous games.


[h1] Final thoughts [/h1]

Even though I haven't played that much hack and slay in general, I still enjoyed this kind of experience. 
I think this game is a great addition to the persona franchise and a fresh take on the hack and slay genre. 
The only thing I can recommend in addition is playing the main game before touching this game, to improve your understanding of the following story as well some parts of the gameplay.

1232.content:
[i][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/35145066/] Feel free to follow my review page![/url][/i] and my twitch https://www.twitch.tv/nightserg

[h1]The gist of it:[/h1]
Persona 5 Strikers is an action hack&slash spin-off/sorta sequel for the fantastic rpg, Persona 5, which sadly has not been released on PC, a game that fans will surely love even in a different gameplay style. 

👍 [u]The good parts:[/u]
+The same characters you loved in P5 are back with all their great chemistry. 
+Initially combat seems a mess but as you get deeper into it, especially on Hard, it gets quite fun and challenging at times. 
+Most of the music from P5 is back but there are some nice new songs as well.
+Boss fights.

👎[u]The bad parts:[/u]
-You need to play Persona 5 on PS4 else it will be incredibly hard to follow.
-The story presentation is almost the same as the original P5 but with a different coating. 

[h1]Story[/h1]
Persona 5 Strikers is in an odd spot for what it is. What I mean by that is, it does continue after the events of the original Persona 5 but the Royal version which is arguably much better is not canon in Strikers which puts it in a weird place. Unfortunately, you still need to play Persona 5 or Royal, to understand and appreciate the story and its characters. I say unfortunately but that isn't really a bad thing because you should 100% play the original games because they're amazing. 

Now onto Persona 5 Strikers story, you play as Joker again who returns for the summer vacation back to Shibuya. As he gets back together with the gang he again ends up in the prison where everything started in the original P5. He is warned that another calamity is about to happen just like before, even worse, and it's up to the Trickster to stop it again. 

This time around you encounter Jails instead of Castles which are at their core the same but with a different skin/background. I won't spoil their nature but suffice to say they follow the same pattern, you roam around the maps which are more open now due to the nature of the gameplay, fight enemies, then the final boss, calling card all that, and repeat several times. Even the way the ending is presented is similar, you'll understand once you reach it. 

You will meet new characters and some of them will even join your group to help you fight the upcoming calamity. As for the original cast, they're all back and they're all the same as you know and love them. Their presence is what makes the Persona 5 series great. Be warned though the game has a lot of dialogue in its full 45 hours and you'll be spending even an hour or more just listening and reading. 

Story rating: 8/10

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
As I've mentioned before P5S is a spin-off because this time around it's not a turn-based rpg anymore but an hack&slash with few rpg mechanics borrowed from the original game. 

The core is there but simplified and turned into action. You roam around the maps, attack the enemies, and engage in combat but instead of turn-based, they now spread around the map and you basically Devil May Cry their ass using the Personas you gather or create which is the specific skill of the Trickster. The abilities and the Personas are the same but "ported" to live-action combat. What that means is besides slashing your way through huge waves of enemies, you can also use skills that you are familiar with in an aoe pattern. 

Obviously, you will not be fighting alone and 3 of your preferred teammates will be there to assist you. They have their own AI and will use skills and attacks but you can switch to them and play as them if you want to which is highly encouraged especially on Hard. You cannot swap your teammates in combat, only outside, so make sure before a boss or tough sub-boss to be prepared who you have by your side. Their skills are also exactly the same as the original so you won't have to worry much about that if you played it. The spell combinations, technical damage, Persona, and enemy weakness are all back so really not much is changed at its core besides how combat is displayed. Boss fights are challenging on Hard but fair and they're really fantastic how they crafted and adapted the mechanics to the hack &slash style. 

As P5S is no longer an rpg, all the bonds and talking and everything else you were used to in the original is gone or simplified. The bond system is a simple talent tree in which you spend points you gather progressively through the story and some side quests. Crafting Personas is also very simplified. If this were an actual rpg with mechanics improved from the original, it would've been an amazing experience but hey at least you can still cook stuff so that's a plus. 

Gameplay rating: 8/10

[h1]Audio[/h1]
Obviously, you can play the game with the English cast or the Japanese cast. I prefer Japanese games, set in Japan, to be played with their original voices, not dubs and I will always recommend it that way. Their voices fit well with their characters and if you played the original you'll feel right back at "home". The new cast also does a pretty great job at getting you emotionally invested. 

The music is mostly from the original, which is of course, great, but there are some fantastic new tunes, especially the boss ones. As for the sound effects and everything else, all is good, no issues whatsoever. 

Audio rating: 8.5/10

[h1]Graphics, performance and tech analysis[/h1]
For a console port, I can safely say it's a pretty good job. Not great, not perfect but still good considering this is the second Persona game on PC. It's still only locked to 60 FPS and there aren't that many graphical settings and as usual, the draw distances are weak but not much of an issue.  The game looks crisp in higher resolutions and details and combat effects and spells and whatnot are all nice to look at. 

There are some crashes and it can be very annoying since there will be times where saving is very scarce and you just have to redo parts of the game or a long boss fight. Other than that, I have not encountered any other issues.

Graphics, performance and tech analysis score: 7.5/10

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
If you haven't played Persona 5, then I don't think I can recommend Strikers but if you have there's absolutely no reason not to play it even if the gameplay is different. The characters you love are back and the story while similar in its beats, is still something nice to experience. 

[h1]Final score: 8/10[/h1]

1242.content:
After 36 hours in I can safely say that this is not the Persona 5 experience I was hoping to get. The best thing about Persona 5 was how it blended together two different genres in one - JRPG and school simulator. Here you only have one genre - hack and slash with a little bit of RPG thrown in. This means that most of the time you will be doing the same things and that is it. And if you are not into the story, you will be left burned out from the experience. 

On the plus side I was pleasantly surprised that the iconic style of Persona 5 has been implemented into the new gameplay and locations. Also, the story is captivating and imaginative like in the past instalments and I do love the road-trip-in-the-summer vibe. The characters stay true to themselves and there are plenty of funny and touching moments with them. Not surprisingly the music is a blast and I do like that through DLC you may get the remastered versions of the previous games' battle music to play during the combat. Finally, the addition of cooking was a nice touch as well. Yes, there is sort of a cooking mechanic in the original P5, but here you need to first unlock the meal through a recipe, which can be collected in various ways, and then you need to gather the needed materials to prepare the meal as well.  

Where Persona 5 Strikers disappoints is in the core gameplay, environments and playability. While interesting at first, the hack-and-slash quickly becomes boring and predictable, even if it uses the weakness and Persona systems from P5. I prefer the turn-based combat as there the gameplay did not feel the same even after 100 hours in. You got the negotiations, the all-out-attacks and ambushes were more meaningful, the single vs all spells were more distinctive from one another, which Persona you had with you was more crucial. Here the gameplay practically boils down to casting spells, to which the enemies are weak, until you get to all-out-attack. Everything else has been simplified way too much. You can heal and restore SP via items at any time without any repercussions. Futaba tells you the weakness of the enemy in the beginning of the fight - bosses as well. You do not need to take down every single enemy to trigger an all-out-attack. Also, there was something terrifying and at the same special when you had to face off several enemies at once in the original P5. Here, because there are literally hordes of enemies sometimes you won't even notice some of them and they will soon all blend in together. 

The jails, themselves, have kept the unique environments from Persona 5 and they are not simply hallways. However, the feeling is the same as the one in Persona 4 - you go to a jail, do the same thing and end up in the same spot over and over again. There are no intricate puzzles, no surprise roadblocks or challenges. The formula is so far the same and thus, the locations feel the same, even if they are unique in their environments. The locations are also not exempt from this - sure, you will see plenty of Japanese cities, but essentially what you are getting per city are two mini locations filled with the same convenience stores and vending machines. Also, you can not do any extra activities in the cities - it is all just roaming the same street several times, buying several items and then going back to the Jail. Sure, occasionally if you talk to a member of the Phantom Thieves they might give you a side quest, which involves more than simply going up and down the map. However, the quests, themselves, are nothing that special and the missed opportunity to have a different version of a mini-game in each city is surely missing. 

Finally, while I said that there are plenty of character moments you are not involved with the characters that much, apart from the main story. One of the strongest aspects of Persona 5 were the interactions you had with the Phantom Thieves and the confidants, which happened outside of the main narrative. In Persona 5 Strikers you only get some boring side quests (like I mentioned) and some lines regarding the city / the particular moment in the story. 

I feel like I would be in the minority of people, who expected more of the game and were left disappointed, but I had to write this review down for anybody like me, who felt in love in Persona 5 and were eagerly anticipating this game. And can you blame me - they made Persona 5 Strikers look like it is a sequel to Persona 5. Apart from the story, it is anything but a sequel.

1245.content:
TDLR; Very fun gameplay but has only a decent story that gets the job done, has tedious grinding, and some pc port issues. 


Before I start there're a few things I'd like to note. PLEASE for the love of god wait for a patch. Now that I've been playing for longer the more and more issues I've been having with the pc version. It crashes often, leading me to lose progress, I've lost around 4 hours of progress in total which has been extremely infuriating. [b][EDIT: This issue has been resolved in the latest beta hotfix][/b]Performance has had dips, while not constant they're noticeable. The settings that come with the game do almost nothing, so i had to go into Nvidia control panel to make AA myself. At this point I cannot progress through one of the last jails because of a loading screen that makes my game crash each time. I do recommend the actual game but don't buy right now, will edit if there is a fix. 

Here's the actual review:

Wow ok I am pleasantly surprised by this game. At first I was worried about it being another generic warriors game but I looked into the game more and it looked more like a Persona game than warriors which is the case. So if you're worried about that, don't be. I've also been surprised of how big the jails are, you can run around them freely for the most part except from a few linear sections and minor puzzles.

The combat is so fluid. It incorporates almost all elements of Persona 5 in one way or another. You can pause time and use specials to hit an enemies weakness and then all out attack is just as satisfying as it was in Persona 5, whilst not as flashy.  Baton passes, 1 mores, buffs/debuffs, futaba support all make their way into the game as well. Fusing personas and using them in battle is still in the game, but not as expanded, which is fine and I only noticed a few times after forgetting. You can blast through the game for a lot of it but with minimal effort except the boss fights, the difficulty scaling is a little whacky. 

The story is worse than Persona 5 but it does have its charm. The story feels like a copy and paste for the first 2 jails but kind of picks up around the fourth jail, which I'm glad it did. The layout of the first two jails also feel similar which i'm confused by since they are supposed to be different. For what the story is overall, it's decent enough to warrant another journey with the phantom thieves.

Some misc. gripes I have with the game is that you never have enough SP so SP items are essential though they're hard to get in large quantity, but you can leave and re enter the jail with no penalty. The grinding in this game is so unnecessarily shitty for late game personas, it requires much lower level personas to reach a threshold in level before you fuse them. How do you level them up? Persona Points which are given in low quantities and increase the amount needed to level up a persona each time, this made completing the registry worse than in vanilla Persona 5 and Persona 5 Royal. Camera can also be whacky but isn't a huge deal.

If I had to rate the game I'd give it a 8/10.

1249.content:
Sadly I can't recommend this at present.

But first, before getting to the very specific reasons why, some of the many positives:
[list]
[*]It's by far the best Warriors-type game out there. The idea to just fully remove the big mass combat maps sounds crazy and like it would completely break such a game, but it turns out it does just the opposite, it makes the combat able to use far more abilities and intricacies because there's only 20-30 enemies now, not 400-1000.
[*]Persona 5 oozed style at every corner, and this carries the torch perfectly. Even the menus are - once again - overstylized to hell and back, the game is full of fancy animations, all fitting the theme.
[*]Speaking of theme, wow the audio is even better than P5 or P5R. It really raises the bar for such games.
[*]Combat is surprisingly challenging depending on difficulty chosen, because counters, interactions and avoidance have a lot of meaning and you can die in 2-3 hits if you use the wrong character at the wrong moment.
[*]The story - as far as I can tell yet - is quite good, and easily blows anything any Warriors game has done before out of the water.
[/list]

So, why no recommendation? Well, there's the problem that a significant amount of people experience quite frequent crashes to desktop. Sure, most games exhibit these for some hardware configurations but here it seems more that a majority see them, most people just rather rarely. And some people see them a lot. Also from reports around the web it seems those who have the accidentally released denuvoless version installed do [b]not[/b] suffer from these crashes. 

So what I'm trying to say is: You may want to hold off until they patch out Denuvo.

1250.content:
Bringing this game to Steam was a good move, but players really NEED the original Persona 5 or Royal first. Atlus should port that next to be fair. With that said:

If you're a Persona fan considering skipping this game because:

1)It's not "real Persona/Megaten"
2)It's not turn-based
3)There is no Social Link/Dating mechanic
4)It's not The Royal (Although please do not play this before at least vanilla P5)


PLEASE reconsider. This is in every sense still a very Persona game.


To say this is not true Persona is the equivalent of saying Persona is not true SMT. They are in the same family and are loyal to the spirit of the series. P1 and P2 did not have social link too.


Trust me when I say Atlus has gone to great lengths to ensure this game FEELS like a sequel to Persona 5.


This game is missing some elements which might disappoint Persona fans:

-There is no social link/confidant
-Persona fusions are extremely streamlined
-The combat is (obviously) not turn-based
-The calendar system is fully controlled by plot, nothing actually passes time
-SP depletes SUPER fast in the early game, but after a couple dozen hours I've begun to appreciate spreading out skills cleverly with normal attacks and combos. Leaving the dungeon to regenerate has no time penalty but is a bit of a time waster, should just have an option to skip the animation entirely tbh


DESPITE THIS:

-There's an abundance of "social-like" events and cutscenes, they're just integrated into the plot
-Some are actually optional and are nice breathers very loyal to Persona fashion. Some of these are also in the form of requests/sidequests.
-There's also a Confidant-like system that applies only to the Phantom Thieves. It's mostly automatic but there are actions you can take to increase the rank further. Rather than 10 ranks with set bonuses, you gain points to invest in skills of your choosing
-The Palaces (or "Jails") are pretty well designed from what I have played of them and are much longer compared to P5 to compensate for the shorter calendar. They are HUGE. Plenty of verticality in some parts and nice platforming.
-Yes it's simplified, but fusions are still pretty fun and skill inheritance plays a role
-BUFFS, buffs are still important in this game. If you're skilled you can chip away at bosses with low level.
-The combat is stellar and definitely not a pushover, because the Persona menu stops time, it somehow still feels like Megaten, you're just not taking turns... Play the game on HARD if you have the guts for it, you'll feel like a boss when clutching bosses with 1HP left. A well prepared player can literally NUKE bosses without taking damage.
-Being able to control all Phantom Thieves and swapping between them in combos feels great
-There are many more areas to explore since this game covers a road trip, incuding P5's Shibuya
-Early parts of each Jail kinda feel like Persona 4's Intel gathering segments, but here there's a percentage on screen so you know when there's actual progress (less guessing)

In the 4 days of early access (Pre-Order) I've had 2 crashes to desktop after a cutscene. It was very random and I barely had any other issue.

Tips (You can probably ignore this if you wanna go 100% blind but there's no story mentioned here):

-FPS has 2 settings, 30 and 60fps, I believe you cannot unlock this.
-If your computer can handle it, set the resolution scale to 2.0x or at least 1.5x. At 1.0 the game's antialiasing is nearly non-existant.
-Use the tutorials menu! It's the only place you'll learn combos and they're **CRUCIAL**
-Shops restock based on plot and battles too, not just the calendar! Always check when you return from the metaverse AND make sure you know what shops have what so you don't waste yen. (YES even the vending machine trash is VERY IMPORTANT in this game, mostly early tho)
-Just like items are important, don't ignore cooking. It's very good.
-Use BOND skillpoints wisely. Money and Shop Sale are very good, but all of them matter.
-Upgrading the shop sale BOND skill will restock the shop, use this very wisely!
-Revisiting Jails has value as the requests system makes a return

1251.content:
Looking cool, Joker!

A really fun sequel to the original Persona 5, continuing the story 6 months after the original game, and mostly keeping up with the standards for story set by its predecessor, albeit retreading many of the same paths, leaving the plot extremely derivative of the original, though making up for that in strides with its characters!

With an action-based combat system similar to the Dynasty Warrior games, the classic Persona fusing mechanics, and a whole heap of style, the combat is a joy to experience, especially with each Phantom Thief bringing something unique to the table! 
Definitely feeling a lot more like a Persona game than a Dynasty Warriors one.

Although it is a shame that the social sim aspect of the original isn't present in this game, the cast and the story of this game is just as interesting! The story makes sure to show off the bonds the members of the Phantom Thieves have with each other, actually presenting them as a group of friends, something I feel the original was missing, and keeps much of the original presentation. Not quite reaching the same highs as the the original, but good nonetheless, carried almost entirely by its interesting and fun characters.

Unfortunately the game comes with several technical issues. 
Due to the pandemic the English cast had to record their lines from home, and it really shows. While their performances are just as spectacular as in the original Persona 5, the audio quality and mixing is all over the place with certain lines being hardly audible, especially near the very beginning of the game, though it does get better and less noticeable as the game goes on.
The game also suffers from terrible aliasing and texture compression that makes it look like the image is built out of Minecraft blocks, and a faulty Anti-Aliasing solution that makes everything look smudged, including the text, which is a real shame because the UI and art of this game ooze style, just like Persona 5! The ability to increase render scaling does help to alleviate some of the issues, so marginally, the image quality can look better than on the PlayStation consoles.
Coupled with a 60 FPS cap and no analogue movement support, makes this merely an OK port.

That is, [u][b]if the game works for you at all[/b][/u]. The version available for purchase right now is filled with many issues that directly inhibit your ability to play it. From infinite loading screens and constant crashes to just annoyingly long load times. With these severe issues seemingly being caused by the Denuvo DRM used for the game as the accidentally released DRM-Free version that came out with the Digital Deluxe edition pre-release suffers from none of these.
Although users have found some supposed workarounds, the best way to fix this seems to be to somehow acquire the DRM-Free version of the executable.

If you are able to overcome the constant crashing and infinite loading times, the rest of these issues are easy to look past though with the fast paced action, charming characters, and the fun times you'll have with the Phantom Thieves in this sequel!

[spoiler] Haru best girl. [/spoiler]

1270.content:
I've put a lot of hours into both Warriors games and Shin Megami Tensei games - and I enjoyed the original Persona 5, so I was excited to play Strikers. Now, having beaten the game, I can say that Strikers is one of the stronger games in its genre.

The gameplay of Strikers makes it a very enjoyable game. The game mixes the beat-em-up gameplay of Warriors games and the adventure gameplay of Persona, with some sprinkling of what feels like an Ys game. You'll progress through dungeons fighting Shadow after Shadow as the Phantom Thieves, and is what you'll spend most of your time doing. Each member of the Phantom Thieves have distinct skills and fighting styles, with my favorites being Inari's ice/counter and Noir's Psi/Gun fighting styles. This hasn't been the first time Persona has taken a step out of the comfort zone, and this game does it well. Unfortunately, this gameplay change also does away with the day-to-day life-sim aspect that Persona's iconic for in favor of a more linear schedule - time won't progress until you do the objective. This in turn removes the Confidant system (in favor of Bond XP leveling system), so any character-fleshing-out is going to only happen during the story. This isn't a huge turn-off for me, but for how much this game feels like just an action-Persona title, it's a shame that sort of thing wasn't included.

Strikers is also very strong aesthetically. It hasn't changed much from Persona 5, but that isn't a bad thing. Exploring the dungeons, while admittedly formulaic at times, remains enjoyable over the 30 hour journey due to not only the enjoyable combat, but also due to varying environments and soundtrack. New songs add to the ambiance of dungeon exploration, while remixes of old Persona 5 favorites pumping energy into the combat. Like its predecessor, Strikers is very strong stylistically.

For better or for the worse, the story is very much what you would expect from an SMT game - [spoiler]  teenagers fighting ever stronger enemies until they kill god [/spoiler]. Still, I think the strongest parts of an SMT story is represented in its characters. While the Phantom Thieves have their time to shine, much more of the spotlight is given to new characters Sophia and Zenkichi, so it's a good thing these characters are likable.  I found Sophia to be very adorable and good comic relief, with Zenkichi being even stronger comic relief. It's a shame they get more of a focus than the original team, but they're well written enough to be enjoyable elements of the story.

This game is not standalone; I do not think you can play Strikers without expecting to be spoiled with the plot of Persona 5. Various plot elements of the previous game are talked about in Strikers - such as plot and ending elements of Persona 5, or retroactively spoil the original game - why are characters in the original game not in this one? If you're already familiar with the plot of the original or Royal or don't care about being spoiled, you can jump right in, but otherwise I cannot recommend this as the starting point of Persona 5 newcomers.

The one major gripe I have with Strikers is the sole technical issue I've had with the game - the crashes. Roughly during every session I play the game - after about two to four hours - the game will crash, usually during a transition between dungeons and Japan or traveling to/from the Velvet room. I save rather aggressively, so I basically never lost any progress, but if you're worried about that sort of thing and rely on autosaves you should probably wait for a future patch.

TLDR: Persona 5 Strikers is a worthy sequel to Persona 5, featuring charming characters, engaging combat, and a great aesthetic. Any fan of both of Persona and Warriors based combat is sure to enjoy this game, but people who haven't yet experienced Persona 5 or wary of crashes should purchase in the future instead.

1277.content:
NOTE: to those who may be stuck on the initial loading screens when opening the game: Hit Alt+Enter to change the game from Windowed Mode to Fullscreen, or vice versa. I found it worked for me.

Some background. I've played P3FES, P4G, and P5 vanilla, and I was so excited for this game. However, If you're looking for an RPG experience like the typical persona games, you won't find it here. It is a more "on the rails" linear storyline. That being said, if you enjoy hack and slash gameplay or are invested in the characters, I can't reccomend the game enough. All the praises I could say about the game, you will likely hear from the others. What I do want to do is give some notes for those who are on the fence about the game/wonder about technicalities about the PC port.

Some notes:
       - As many have noted, this game has a LOT going on at once on your screen. The combat starting out will be clunky, stiff, and a bit challenging at first. You could say there is a bit of a learning curve when it comes to this game. But give it some time and you'll eventually learn to filter out the noise and navigate battles like an expert. Making use of your dash and your special (Y button on the controller) will allow for some of the most fluid combat I've gotten a chance to play in a hack and lash.

       - This game is an anti aliasing nightmare. If you can, before starting a new game, turn on anti aliasing and crank up the resoulution scale to 2.0. In classic persona fashion, you won't be able to access the pause menu until you get through the tutorials.

        - This game is locked to 60fps. It's a real shame considering I wanted to make full use of my 144hz monitor, but we'll have to see if we'll get a community mod for that, or if it's set to 60 because the game logic will break because of a high framerate.

        - The voice mixing in this game is kind of horrendous. Characters sound different (especially joker) and in some parts, voices are too quiet, like the VAs were standing too far away from the microphones. Still, this is an amazing feat considering that all of the voicework was recorded from home due to COVID-19 restrictions

        - The battles are fairly easy for me, and I've played only a few hack and slash's growing up. If you are a hack and slash expert, I'd put the difficulty on "hard". You are free to change the difficulty whenever you wish during the game.

        -  There is a lot of reading, like traditional persona games. If you're not into that, you may want to give picking this up a second thought.  If you have never played Persona 5, I reccomend watching a playthrough or playing it yourself before jumping into this game as it does not give much background into the plot of P5.

This game is a whole lot of fun, and I want to thank the developers at Atlus for putting in the time to port this game to PC. Here's hoping for the other persona games to come to PC!
